description:
I am surprised to see this place only gets 2 1/2 stars. I came here early in the morning around 710ish. There were many guys inside ordering togo, they kept standing by the counter after they have paid and I was like wth, then the dim sum lady turns around and I immediately knew why, the lady or should I say young girl is pretty good looking, I kid you not, compare to other dim sum ladies around Chinatown, she is the prettiest of them all haha, oh wel.... not only that, she is very friendly and polite too and tries her best to sell you some other dim sum while you order. 

Great selections of dim sum items and porridge at reasonable price. Few tables for you to dine in if you choose and they offer boba tea.
author: William C.

description:
We were looking for a quick bite while strolling through Chinatown on our little vacation in San Francisco, and we came across this place! The prices looked wonderful, and so was the dim sum! I ordered 2 plates at first, and I loved the shrimp dim sum so much, I went to order a third, and the cashier actually recommended another variant -- delicious! If you are looking for an experience where the staff actively try and help you experience new tastes (I hadn't even tried dim sum before), this is a pretty cool spot! I'll definitely be back next time my partner and I are in town!

谢谢！
author: Cole S.

description:
Was looking for a place that had a chicken+veggie bun and this was the only place close enough and had no line. The bun was okay, but I did feel annoyed by the workers, who felt the need to talk shit about their patrons in Chinese..right in front of them. Too bad, I understood them? I didn't expect much, but seriously...

A caution of warning... Another thing I noticed while eating my buns... We got 2 buns for $2.25 (already not a deal). A white lady came in and got one bun and was charged $2. Poor lady looked so happy to get it for $2. Yikes.
author: Adrienne L.

description: Yummy deep fried wontons and taro dumpling. I think they changed the boos. Everything getting so much better. Highly recommended.
author: Shengzongzhao Z.

description: Looking for no thrill cheap dim sum? Here you go. You could get it to go, or eat in. Don't expect a fancy place, they just have few tables (upstairs also) you could use. Most orders were $2.50 for 3 pieces, decent size, decent quality. You could almost categorize them as street food.
author: Eddie D.

description: A cheap little dim sum place! No line and nice service from the ladies at front. I didn't see much of an issue and I was surprised to see the place has only two stars! The place seems like a hole in the wall, but we all liked it. For $1 a piece of dumpling, it was good. The beef dumpling was a good size! This is my second time passing by here, and the seating is pretty limited so I always take my food outside and walk around. It's a nice little go-to snack!
author: Katrine U.

description:
I would only go here if this was the last resort. And last Saturday, it was the last resort- at least, for me and my friends. All the other dim sum to go places were hustling and bustling with customers and we could tell from all the lines out the doors. 

But House of Dim Sum was not busy at all. There was no line, there was a very limited and available seating area (hint, hint- which we somehow missed) and various kinds of dim sum. We ordered about $20 worth or 12 pieces including a small fried rice.

Different textures, different tastes but the same disappointment and dissatisfaction throughout. 

Most of the dim sum was cold and I just chewed on the meat (pork, I think) until I worked up the courage to swallow. The shrimp was just a tad better. 

I'm sorry House of Dim Sum, I wanted to like you, but I couldn't for the life of me. This place needs improvement. Then maybe I could reconsider going again.
author: Cassandra P.

description: I originally wanted Delicious Dim Sum across the street, but they were closed for Chinese New Year. They had a line, but it moved quickly. You have to order quickly, and they're not the friendliest. The food is cheap and nothing special.
author: Ha D.

description:
This place advertises itself as a grab and go dim sum place.  It does that, but with a cost.  No biggie if the food is good I'm game paying more for good food... but it was Utterly disgusting.  

Considering this is in the heart of China town, during Chinese New Year, and other  dim sum places were packed, I figured give this place a try.  

Sadly, this place did NOT deliver.  Food was COLD not even steamed.  Prices were NOT listed.  Place is super dirty.  

The food IS home made and NOT store bought.  But it feels as though the food was made in bulk with the anticipation that it will sell during Chinese New Year regardless of quality or taste.

I can not recommend this place especially given there are so many other places in the same area serving dim sum.  

Advice to owners: When you KNOW places are gonna be packed and your restaurant isn't doing well, Chinese New Year is the BEST time to gain popularity because people who do not wanna wait WILL visit even the emptiest of places.  Capitalize on this and deliver outstanding everything, word will spread.

Also: heat your food before serving, especially if your customer chooses the "dine in" option.
author: Nathan S.

description:
The house of dim sum is good as is we got full for cheap but ehh in everything. The shop is easy to access, it's right off the road! When we got inside they have a women who is there to collect your order and you order by telling her what items you want off the picture menu on the wall. I got so many dumplings! I would highly recommend the pork dumplings and the boa buns with BBQ pork inside, fan favorites for sure. We then got a plate of fried rice that looked a little suspect, we decided to give it a chance anyways. Total $24 for all that food, not bad! 

We ended having to sit upstairs due to the tables being taken on the first level. I have to say this place would have gotten 4 stars if it was just cleaner. Halfway through lunch I had to brace myself to use the restroom and I found out how long I could hold my breath for.
author: Nicole K.

description: Horrible service I will never go there again Besides there's so many other places to choose from in Chinatown but these people could probably care less probably because we were in Chinese I got a feeling of being discriminated against but what are you gonna do go to another place don't go here
author: Laura S.

description:
3.5 stars. 

After strolling around Chinatown in the morning, it was pretty obvious that most of the restaurants order from the same vendor for their supply of food. Typically I would have made my way up the hill to Stockton, but decided to hit Yelp and was like, "why not?"

The 2 stars didn't scare me away from House of Dim Sum, I proceeded to enter. Inside was lady at the counter who took my order and let me know what was available. Fortunately I'm able to use my broken Cantonese and get by with some orders of Ha Gao (shrimp dumpling) and Ngau Siu Mai (beef dumpling). 

I typically come in the morning around 7:30 am. The quality of food is pretty much the same as the ones on Stockton. There was a pretty good variety to choose from but I typically stick with my staple order. 

I definitely wouldn't sleep on this place!
author: Sam K.

description:
Service was terrible. Though there was no one else there, the lady at the counter kept trying to rush us as we were looking at the menu. We ordered some steamed food, along with some fried rice. Everything went onto flimsy paper plates and then into the microwave. Our "plates" were tiny hot dog trays--not even actual paper plates like the ones the food was served on. We took a seat at a dirty, sticky table and hoped the food would at least be okay. Unfortunately, the fried rice either was made with severely undercooked rice or was a few days old, because it was extremely hard in texture. The dim sum was "meh", but everything quickly turned into "bleh!" when we saw the counter lady walk into the bathroom with her food service gloves on and walk out WITH THE SAME GLOVES STILL ON. We high-tailed it out of there. Would never go back.

P.S. If after reading this review you're still brave enough to try this place out, remember to bring cash. I had to run to the Citibank after we ordered because they don't take cards.
author: Fay T.

description:
The dim sum was put into a microwave when I ordered it. 

When I asked, "Where's my bubble tea?" The clerk said, "Later, later."

Overall, a sloppy dim sum takeout place not worth your time. Try the place right across the street, where the dim sum is fresher and tastier.
author: Rick C.

description: It good place for dim sum and the service pretty good. I love shrimp dumplings. I wanna with my friend go next time
author: Mavis Y.

description: Busy location. When ordering be ready.  They tend to move fast.  I usually get shu mai and shrimp dumplings. Better ordering it here then the restaurants. Price wise better for your buck.
author: Jose R.

description: We had to come back and return the pork buns we bought. It tasted old and chemical like. They took it back without question, thinking maybe they knew about it. Then they didn't want to refund our money either. The rest of the food was not good as well. Will not come back. We used to go across the street to delicious dimsum, but the lady was rude to us last time. But their food is actually much better, you just have to endure the lady talking smack in chinese while she picks your order.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
So came here for a change and realized I am never coming back. Got tired of waiting in line at one spot and getting sick of another 2 around the corner and just wanted to try something new. Should have known when I had seen there wasn't a single person in the place. 

Got inspired to come here by 3 Brink employees that looked like they were going to rob the place. The funny part was that the Brink employees were just guys with too much attitude hosting a gun.
author: M C.

description: It is your typical take out dim sum place. It is cheaper than sit down but still comparable to other lunch places. They could have list prices on their menu, I was just told when I finish ordering. They have 3 tables so you might have to share. The soy sauce and hot sauce is on the table. They don't have a free water disperser so they'll push bottle water or soda instead.
author: Tony C.

description:
This place ummmmm let's see the women rushed us to make an order and it was difficult to order  bcuz of many varieties and unfamiliarity on my part. All of the dim sum I didn't care for at all and it was expensive. 
The only one I would go back for and was a huge portion and delicious was the shrimp and chives it was so delicious. Either way I'm glad I found this place.
author: Lika G.

description:
I found this place strolling around for a dim sum place at 8am on a Monday morning. I'm glad I did not check its yelp review prior to ordering a takeout order of dim sum. Was nice that I was the only customer there .. no waiting.
It is a smaller place that is untidy looking. They have limited seating in the restaurant.  
They have steamed dim sum in bamboo steamers. It was a good selection. The woman who was at the counter was friendly and happy to show me the different types of dim sum available. Added plus is that they are in front of the glass counter so easy to see.
I ordered the har gow, shui mei, beef rice noodle, and the spinach dumplings for takeout. They throw them all in the same plastic container. Give you some dim sum soy sauce. I got a takeout container of hot chili oil from the table. They were steaming hot and tasted great especially with the dim sum soy sauce and hot chili oil. The order came out to $10 which I thought was a fair price.
No complaints here. Dim Sum was delicious.
author: Joe L.

description:
Quick and easy

Order dim sum and u can get it right away 

Go sit upstairs

Think they charge quite a lot tho 


6 piece for $5 

Usually can get more with $5

If u on the go or need some quick food this is a spot for ya
author: Chiu H.

description:
***Heath Inspectors***

Went in and tried this place for bbq pork buns. The taste was stale, no sweet bbq taste. Took two bites and into the garbage.

My coworker grabbed one and jumped. Look what he found. And she has an egg in her.
author: patrick s.

description: A great dim sum place in Chinatown San Francisco. All the usual items available and all good. Lots of pastries too.
author: Peter K.

description:
Interestingly terrible place. Interesting because of the concept of the place, terrible because of the food. I find it interesting that SF has several dim sum places that are primarily for takeout. Places like these might have 1-3 tables max.

Also "interesting" because this place has absolutely zero allure. There's no effort on the part of this place to make it look attractive. The fluorescent lights don't help either. Alright I'll cut it some slack. It's in Chinatown and is primarily for take out. 

The food is terrible. Oy vey. 

Char siu bao
-- dough is sweet?! There's more dough than filling

Deep fried taro puff
-- there's more taro than filling

Pan fried taro slices
-- hard like don't know what

Crepe with scallions and dried shrimp
-- tastes ok but where's the sweet soy sauce that's supposed to come with it?

Steamed pork ribs
-- just not good

The lady just piles the various dim sum items together on the plate. That means the steamed pork ribs and the "au jus" (though more like oil instead of au jus) are poured out from the dim sum bamboo steamer onto a serving plate. Then she piles on the pan fried taro slice and crepes onto the same serving plate. Great. What an appetizing way to eat dim sum.
author: Teri Y.

description: I went here for some shrimp dim sum because it was the closest place to where I was. Do. Not. Recommend. The dim sum was good but it made my stomach hurt and head ache super quickly. I felt like crap after eating here.
author: Abby A.

description: Tried their fried sesame ball because I was craving some and it was really not tasty. I was very disappointed because it was cold even though there were plenty that looked as if they just came out. It's a really accessible location right in the center of Chinatown, but unfortunately the taste is just not there.
author: Momona Y.

description:
I was walking through Chinatown while in San Francisco and thought, "I haven't had dim sum in a while." I Googled dim sum and I decided to try House of Dim Sum. And ZOMG, this place has some of the tastiest dim sum I've had in a long time.

-- WHAT TO ORDER --
I didn't know what the proper terms were for the food I was thinking of so I texted a bunch of friends. What I was craving were pork buns (char siu bao) and pork hash (char siu mai).

If you're going to go a dim sum place, you *need* pork buns (steamed, and baked ones), along with those round sesame dessert balls. Those three things were what I was familiar with and none of them disappointed; they were all incredibly tasty.

-- SUMMARY --
I've been to too many places with "pork buns" which didn't have much pork and a lot of vegetable filler (yuck). This place had delicious red pork all inside. I ate it all up. I'm coming back here when I visit again. Recommended.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
I love dim sum, but am by no means an expert. This place was quick and fine. Not too much to say about the customer service, they're fast but they kind of rush you out so I recommend knowing exactly what you want before you start ordering. I ordered potstickers (I think it was 5 or 6 of them?), a bbq pork bun and two sesame balls. It ended up being $8

The Potstickers were just fine, some of their wrappers were tough and a bit hard.

I liked that the bbq pork bun, and it wasn't too sticky which was nice.

The sesame balls were also fine, not mind blowing. It has more filling than some I've had which could be good or bad depending on your taste. I wish they were warm though. 

Everything I got was either lukewarm or cold.
author: Elena K.

description: If you know what you want, don't mind the hole in the wall look, and don't need a line of people to validate your choice, come here, order promptly, pay cash, and enjoy that you just got in and out with a pile of delicious dim sum for a reasonable price without hassle and hype.
author: Kris B.

description: Perhaps I was expecting too much. I thought "dim sum in SFO Chinatown - how can you go wrong?"  Well, I found, very easily apparently. The shumai wasn't the worst I've had but it's pretty high up on that list. Har gow? Forget it. The baked BBQ buns wasn't great either but it was the best of the bunch.  Congee was bland and drowning it in soy sauce didn't make it any better.  Red flag when they heated everything in a microwave right there behind the counter.  I would avoid this place.  If you're really hungry and this was the only place open, starving is the better option.
author: Albert N.

description: 園林點心 in Chinese. Have tea, milk tea, and Chinese dimsum available in Chinatown! There is also another bakery store with some dimsum items across the street.
author: A L.

description:
It was Tess' birthday weekend so what did she want to do? Go to SF to eat sum sum and walk around the pier and go to their big ass Daiso near FiDi. Instead of a restaurant, she said she wanted dim sum from a takeout kind of place. This was nearby based on my Yelp map so we walked in so she can take a look at their selections. 

+ fried rice 
+ egg rolls 
+ beef shiu mai
+ har gow 
+ potstickers 
+ service 

I did not try the fried rice or potstickers but Tess had no complaints. The egg rolls were decent, a little oily but what can I expect? The har gow was enjoyed by Gavin... he barely touched the shrimp but ate the skin instead. The beef shiu mai was tasty but that wasn't what I wanted. I asked for steamed beef meatballs but what I got was that... 

Service was brief and it's a cash only place. There is an upstairs where there are about 5 dining tables and 2 super small restrooms. I cannot rate this fairly since I did not eat the majority of the items I ordered for the kids but they ate it and walked out w/ full tummies. No complaints. Happy 12th, Tess.
author: Tram N.

description: I went with a group of friends and I'm not a fan. I got 3 medium sized potstickers and it was $5.75. $1.50 less than a whole meal!! The worst part, we watched him pull the potstickers out of the microwave! The potstickers were gooey and not crispy at all. I could barely get them to rip when I bit them! Eggs and milk tea weren't great either--says my friend. The free pot of tea was great but that was literally it. I wasn't expecting amazing food but I wasn't expecting microwave $6 potstickers. PLEASE PLEASE DON'T EAT THERE.
author: Emma T.

description:
I wish I could give zero stars (and I rarely say that, let alone write a bad review) DO NOT GO HERE! I don't mind that the place is "gross and dirty" like the other reviewers, this review is strictly on the food itself:
I got the Shanghai dumplings (which did not have soup in them) the "spicy" pork dumplings had no spice let alone any taste at all - they were totally bland, I gave my friend one and she held it in her mouth and walked down the street to spit it out in a trash can... and the shrimp and cilantro dumplings, I don't know what they put in it but it was disgusting. I was very hungry before I ate here and after a few dumplings (hoping the next one would be good) I completely lost my appetite. The only slightly redeeming food here: chickens feet, which was ok, but the dumplings were terrible!! Never been so disappointed, I wish I had checked Yelp! But there appears to be many other good dim sum places close by, being Chinatown and all, but I'm not sure if they are "dim sum to go" like this one. But stay away!! Also cash only ~
author: Nikki R.

description: Really good. Came in and the staff was really helpful. Gave us a sampling and it was only $15. So good
author: Crystal H.

description:
This is by far the worse food I've ever had.  Despite the low rating on yelp, we decided to give it a chance. Especially since there were 12 of us and they had plenty of seating. That too should have been a sign. Most of the food was cold. One of the "fried" wontons was partly  frozen! The wonton soup tasted like water with no flavor.  The chow mein seemed like it was days old. The boba tea was watered down and the actual boba had the texture of raisins. The sesame balls were oily. 

One of our family members actually had to throw up from it. Do yourself a favor and stay away.
author: Rosalia A.

?????????????????????????

GOING TAISHANESE STYLE
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

This place has a fresh assortment of all kinds of good to great Dim Sum, 
some of the best is steaming hot (see pics).
The women who took care of us & were from the same region of China
(TAISHAN) & spoke the same dialect,  were super-nice to us. They told
my lovely wife that the CHIC FEET I SO LOVED there were prep & spiced 
TAISHANESE STYLE.  Many people of this region had/have emigrated
to the US & my wife constantly meets people from her hometown.
Then they surely yack it up, my wife makes new friends, & we get even
better service.

The prices were far lower than any fancy place, but of course the
 three tables, chairs, & such were utilitarian.  The only draw back
is that if the door was open too much your steaming
hot DIM SUM would get cold & not taste so good.
  
The good thing is that
you can order small batches at a time & thus prevent this.  They also have
an assortment of deserts.  Between the taste, the variety, the nice service,
& ample seating, I love the place.  It was not fancy, but it was far better than
the super-popular take out one across the way.  I have NOT A CLUE why
 this place is UNDERRATED.  I was glad,
 since it was not crowded on a weekday.

It was much better than the fancy, but horrid places that get low grades, in
 health inspections in C-town (that Yelp alerts you to)... but poor sanitation 
& service is common, in all but, in the UBER-priced ones 
that are out of C-town & in the business areas of SF.

You are likely fooling yourself if you think that the OVER-YELPED
places, that have absurdly LONG LINES, if the Bay Area are that 
much better in kitchen sanitation (especially certain Waterfront ones!). 

You need to realize that many OTB Chinese who come here & cook,
 do not have a clue about our standards in food prep nor storage.  
My MIL surely does not, but my Nephews & Niece thrive here anyway.
 Even my wife leaves things over-night to my horror.  We both had bouts 
of mild poisoning at home...ugh!  Her brothers, are on the opposite pole & own
 restaurants in either SF Bay Area or Vegas, and get a "A" with health inspections.
I have been back in their kitchens many a time, 
and I tried to get my wife up to those standards.

Anyway, & in conclusion, if you want good fresh
 
DIM SUM & CHIC FEET
''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''
 that tastes great, & don't mind
the ambience of a humble hole-in-the wall 
at bargain prices, go here...

LOADS OF LOCAL
OTB CHINESE ( WHO DO NOT YELP) 
SURELY COME HERE!
author: Paul M.

description:
I recently went here because i was craving some shrimp cheung fun even thought i never had it before, and it was so bland it only had like 4 pieces of shrimp in it and wasn't worth the $2.50 i payed for it more like it could have been better if it was ranging from $1.00 - $1.75 then i could see why it tasted so godly bland! 
Would never go here again 1.2/10
author: Food F.

description: I happened to walk by this place and stopped by to try a few Dim Sum. The place looked questionable and didn't look clean, but I thought how I can go wrong with Dim Dum in Chinatown. Cheap but not really cheap because I ended up throwing away everything. I asked for an extra paper place and the woman who worked there complained. Bad food. Bad customer service.
author: Jade J.

description: My daughter had a field trip. She was buying her lunch. She told me they had NO PLATES only paper ones. And the "BOBA" she had gave  her and everyone in her class who got it a stomachache. The place was dirty. The stairs made your shoes sticky. The food was so cold. If they dropped money in your food they would take out the money and act like nothing happened.
author: Rita Y.

description: Great place for a quick bite of dim sum, don't expect to spend too long here though! Is takeout/ quick dine style. Got the shrimp dumplings ($2.50 for a set of 3), ha gao , shumai and yotiao. Solid choices, would go here for the food but not the experience.
author: Cheechee L.

description: Utterly horrific dim sum. This place is awful on so many levels I don't even know where to start. Maybe I can try to erase this experience from my memory to make me feel better - but I can't, since the horrible stuff is still sitting in my gut. Oh yeah, I saw them microwave my dim sum! Can I wish this place into the cornfield? To think this mess cost me $23 for two. Anyplace else is better than this. So many other, better places...
author: Phil T.

description:
Terrible. Literally the worst dim sum I've ever had. 

The steamed pork bun had cloyingly sweet dough, and we couldn't eat it all,  and ended up eating the pork with a fork.  The fried rice wasn't flavorful and contained several rock hard grains of rice,  as well as overcooked peas.  The taro puffs were cold, since they were kept unheated on top of the glass display case,  which was gross not only because they were chewy, but because cold pork filing is unappetizing. 

To be fair,  the cilantro shrimp dumplings were tasty.

P.S. The bathrooms are super icky.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Sadly, we blew it.  We visited SF's Chinatown and managed to find crappy dim sum.  Dang it!  We actually walked into Delicious Dim Sum, but they only had 2 (occupied) tables, so we wandered over yonder to find somewhere else with seating.  Curses!

At House of Dim Sum, you order with an employee, and s/he'll plate your food on a tray for you to take upstairs where there's tables.  The ha gao (shrimp dumplings) had a weird, elastic, rubbery texture that was extremely off putting.  Fried sesame balls were hard and lackluster, and the char siu bao was 80% dough and 15% bbq pork, and 5% of some substance that was like misplaced mayo.  Eek.  The only really decent dish was the shu mai.

Overall, the dim sum left much to be desired, and the establishment could have been cleaner too.
author: Tricia D.

description:
Tourist trap for sure. Took my wife around Chinatown and she was looking for a fried dumpling with pork inside. We came across this place based on its location (and obvious name).

I felt snacky so she ordered me shu mai dumplings as well. Both items were too salty and packed too much MSG. Both items were $12 for 8 pieces total! Pass this place and keep walking, there are other spots in the area that are much better and worth the extra calories burned.
author: Jon S.

description:
Good spot for dim sum.

They have pictures on the wall just in case you struggle on ordering.  Too much competition with 3 other dim sum spots across the street.

There are a few tables.

Cash only spot.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Don't let the pictures trick you into going here!! Let's start with the fried noodles.... so bland that and flavourless that when we tried to add soy sauce, it just tasted like chewy soy sauce. We also ordered the beef noodle... no sauce on the noodles, flavourless (again), and you can taste the binding agent used in the beef... it was crazy!! Potstickers: ok in flavour but really tough shell. Pork shu mai: good flavour, the best thing we had but not worth stopping for. We got a few other things as well but the descriptions are all the same... flavourless, either mushy or too tough. I will never go here again!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Sweaty, sticky, and the glass is covered in a thin film.... you know the food is authentic. I've definitely had better dim sum, but I come back to this place more for the environment, which I realize sounds awful, but just reminds me of when I used to live in Asia and I love it. 

Cash only so come prepared. I don't speak Chinese, and the ladies don't speak too much English, but pointing at what you want works perfectly fine. I always get chern fun (shrimp in a fat rice noodle) cause its my FAV, and then try something else new every time. The sesame balls are decent, kind of too thick for my fancy but I can't help but order one. If you're getting it to go, they put your food in a plastic bag for you and give you a fork so you can eat it on the street. So authentic. So fun. 

I got 5 different things for $4.75... can't beat that! Also, the dim sum just sits out all day and you definitely want to eat things hot, so I would suggest asking for the food from the bottom trays. 

There's additional seating and a bathroom upstairs.
author: Steph D.

description:
Been using Yelp for a couple of years now. For the most part, it has not steered me wrong. I wish I had n opportunity to open the app before we walked in. Unfortunately, I didn't get to the phone till we had ordered. 

That's when I saw the notification of a poor did safety inspection. Too late, already brought our own food to the dirty tables upstairs. 

Food is not impressive at all, as expected.  Very oily. Not much taste.

Went to ask for a couple more "plates" and got spoken about amongst the two women while they reluctantly gave me these tiny little "plates" to replace the ones they gave us that were dirty.
author: Ron W.

description: I went to Yank Sing with my husband yesterday and dropped $50 for two people for 4 dumplings and chicken feet. I was really skeptical of this place and any togo dim sum place. The only complaint I have for this place is the dumplings are not warm, but the flavors are there. We got so much for only $13. Honestly, I would come here over Yank Sing!
author: Jen S.

description:
Worst dim sum I ever had in my life.
I ordered 5 dim sum and wonton noodle soup. 
None of the dim sum was hot. Surprisingly, some of them were not even warm.
I couldn't believe room temperature dumplings.
Wonton noodle soup doesn't have any flavor. It was like noodle in hot water.

Customer service was also terrible.
After I ordered my food, a lady at the counter keep talking to another customer, totally ignored me for waiting to pay. Just like I don't exist there.

Never again.
author: Manatee T.

description: Worse dim sum ever. Wow, can't believe they're in business. If you wan't old, cold, microwaved food, then this is the place. The quality of the food is bad, from the dumplings to the soup, to the crud that was on my soda can (looked like bird poop).
author: Jerry A.

description:
Went here on a whim, plus the boyfriend wanted some Dim Sum. 
Wouldn't come here based on service, yet I was amused by how deciding food was done here since I'm used to sitting down at a table and having food carts go around. Plus the staff seems to push recommendations for you more than friendly suggestions to get you to move on. 
For 10 pieces of dim sum and Thai milk tea, I think I spent about $20. Boyfriend said he liked the taste of the dim sum, and I thought it was okay.
Setting isn't the cleanest, but we handled it.
author: Agnes S.

description: So I was trying to find a dim sum place in Chinatown that opens early in the morning so I decided to give this place a chance. I have to say this is by far the worst Chinese restaurant I've ever been to... even worse than most Americanized Chinese restaurants. The food is cold. The plates are dirty and the service is rude. It's almost like they have something against people who speak mandarin  not Cantonese.
author: Olivia C.

description:
Well, as one other reviewer noted, this is really just a hole-in-the-wall.  But we were on vacation, checking out Chinatown, and up for a little adventure.  I definitely am not a dim sum aficionado.  However, I know whether or not I like something.  My experience was okay.  So I'll rate it accordingly.

The woman behind the counter apparently spoke broken English, and was helpful with our ordering.  However, she also seemed to want to tell us what to get and how much (meaning quite a bit).  But since I didn't really know what to get, and there were five of us, it was fine.  We had a full plate, but it wasn't actually more than the five of us wanted in total.  And it was really quite cheap for the volume.

Now it's just an ordering counter on the left when you walk in, along with a few tables on the right.  But there was some sort of loft area above, and I saw some stairs in the back & peeked up them.  There was a whole area up there in the loft with about a dozen large tables.  So we hauled ourselves up there to relax and gorge on the dim sum.  Yeah, some were a little oily and some were not quite as hot as I would have liked.  But the flavors were goo-oood.  I especially liked the sausage stuffed ones, followed closely by the shrimpers.

So...quick, tasty dim sum.  That's what I wanted.  That's what I got.
author: Doug M.

description: Out of the way dimsum place. I came here during Chinese new year since my usual place was closed because of the holiday. The steamed and baked pork buns tasted the same as other places except that they there were more bread than the filling. Other than that, it was "meh". Will I visit here again? Only if the other place (Dim Sum Bistro) was closed. Every time I visit SF, I would always go to Dim Sum Bistro. They also offer hot porridge with preserved eggs and CHEAP Chinese donuts.
author: Apit L.

description:
Went there for breakfast on Friday morning. It was one of the only place open before 10 in the neighborhood.

Pros: absolutely delicious food, wide choice of Dim Sum, and menu with pictures to help you ordering.

Cons: not the cleanest Chinese restaurant, takes cash only (Chase and Citi ATM at the corner of the street), few tables.
author: Renaud S.

description:
what i ordered... steamed bbq pork bun

...good bun, soft and fluffy but filling is minimal and so-so in taste.

ambiance... ok
service... good (nice and smiley)
cost... $- (inexpensive)
author: Gors P.

description: This place is HORRIBLE, don't go. Disgusting and gross. We had to drink Cokes to destruct the food in our stomachs ha!
author: Thom A.

description: We ordered and PAID for 4 wonton soups and the lady at the register insisted we only paid for 3. Like how does 1 order cost $18.00, bitch can't do math. Fuck this place. My pork bun was also cold, there were flies inside and on the egg custard pies. Also service sucked. DO NOT GO HERE.
author: Raisa A.

description: We came here because golden gate bakery was closed... We bought - variety of dim sum Sui Mai 3 stars hai gow 3 stars shrimp chives 3 stars the chicken bao 3 stars hugh and lots of filling. The egg custard was a day old in the am and meh.  The porridge was plain but good for older people.  The lady was nice and the food is just average.
author: Toma C.

description:
If you remember anything from this review let it be this. Don't just come to House of Dim Sum because it has more open tables than other restaurants in the area. There is a reason for that.

I decided to go to House of Dim Sum after realizing that I wouldn't be able to sit down at the other two spots in the area that I wanted to eat and I regret it.

Walking in, I was confused by what cost what and how everything worked so I quickly just chose a couple of the things that they had in the front and that was hastily suggested to me.

They microwaved the noodles making them dry and gave us the last of their dumplings. Then I chose a couple more things as well. All said and done we ended up with a plate of noodes, 8 dumplings, a black roll, a shrimp roll and two arizonas at a total of 19 dollars. Me and my girlfriend were disappointed, it probably wouldn't be enough to satisfy us, but we dug in anyways.

The noodles were dry, but still had a little flavor and the black roll and the shrimp rolls were tasteless. The best thing on our Plate was the pork dumplings and the way the pork tasted still leaves me questioning the definition of pork.

The only thing I can say about this place is that if you know what you want and they have it ready, you will be in and out. Other than that I cannot suggest it at all.
author: Kieffer W.

description: Avoid! Prices are not posted and I'm sure she tried to overcharge me because I'm white. $4 she wanted for 4 dumplings. Not the going rate. I walked out.
author: Geoffrey U.

description:
This place is disgusting. The lady charged me double than my black hair price. This is discrimination. 
Then I handed her money and was expecting change, but she "forgot" to give me change. Not to mention, my dollar flew into another plate of food because of the wind and she just took the money out of the plate and served the food still. This is the most messed up place ever.
author: Jenny C.

description: So the place was dirty, there was food just sitting out on the counter and someone was sweeping, causing the dirt to just circulate around the food. The woman pushed food on us, then MICROWAVED the plate. She charged us $13. I asked what each item cost. She said $13. It was SOOO greasy and gross and didn't taste fresh at all. Skip it.
author: Es F.

description:
Lots of variety in this little hole in the wall, but almost everything we got was stone cold! The chicken feet were the only warm thing (not hot), and were pretty good, but the salted pork and egg was cold and tough (with very little egg... and pork...), as were the dumplings (good taste though). The sweet rice balls were really good - to share, for sure. The place is pretty dingy and the pricing is made for tourists. 

Oh, and they were out of porridge!! Really??
author: Jacob S.

description: The absolute WORST, ever. Keep walking and eat ANYwhere else. Pork buns cold. Sesame buns HUGE AND raw. Wonton soup BLAND AF. Even the boba tea was undrinkable. I've live in the city for 20 years and this was in my top 5 worst meals of all time. PLUS: the counter lady was very rude and pushy.
author: Jeannie D.

description: The dimsum were okay not appealing at all, the only one I liked was spicy pork Dumpling!
author: Sahil S.

description:
Not much of a selection, but if you have a quick craving for dim sum and want to be in and out, this is the place for you. Has mostly mainstays like shrimp or beef rice rolls (har / ngow cherng), shrimp crystal dumplings (har gow), phoenix talons (fong tzao), shu mai, egg tart (dan tot). Nothing too crazy. 

My favorite, the rice rolls, is how I judge a dim sum place. It's the item that takes the most skill to perfect. House of Dim Sum's rice rolls had the perfect chewiness and fluffiness, but they were a little too thick. Shrimps were cooked nicely, not overcooked, and had bounce to the bite. The sauce was balanced but I wish they smothered the rice roll with it, not just placed a dainty little container of it off to the side.

In summary: Overall, basic, decent quality, cheap, and very quick. The fast food of dim sum.
author: Lawrence H.

description:
Overpriced. Got two boxes of ~8 dumplings and turned out to be $17
Found some weird aluminum and plastic wrap in my dim sum
Fried dumpling skin stale and hard 
The shrimp was not bad
Praying my stomach doesn't hurt later
Go across the street instead!
author: Connie W.

description:
Overall this place it's like 2.5 stars but because they didn't deserve a 3 I.didn't round up so here's why..when you walk in here you are definitely a little intimidated because you don't expect this type of setup especially when I'm used to being catered to..not that I mind but just a little different. From other people I was aware that dim sum sit down restaurants were super expensive here in the BAY so your best option is to go where they offer the pink box full of goodies and take it togo.well they had a sit down area to eat here but boy was it straight ghetto.. the place was old and they gave you paper plates plastic forks and it seemed like when you sat down to eat here it just felt like the place hasn't been cleaned in 20 years..but as for the food it was decent but not your best.
The one gross thing that left a bad taste in my mouth was when I was done I offered to check the restroom and almost threw up all my food..sorry but I.would probably not step for in this establishment ever again..I know it's San FrancIsco and Chinatown is old but no
author: Tommy D.

description:
The food is good and cheap here - but eating off a paper plate with a plastic fork goes against my grain... never the less,  the place is okay... but maybe not "A-Ok".  When I first started going there I made a video of the experience: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UCP97I0Ha60 of the experience.  I was also listening to old music from archive.org, so the video has a cheesy music track with it.

I cannot say that I would seek this place out for lunch if you can afford a $10 lunch - but if you are starving, only have $5 and don't want to walk to Stockton street, this may be for you.
author: Steve S.

description:
Decent dim sum joint. Pretty old school from the looks of the place, so it's a good place to go if you're look for some old school traditional style dim sum. The inside is relatively small, with only 3 small tables, so it's definitely not a sit-down kind of place (note the large "food to go" sign right on the entrance).

Having said that, there is a wide selection of dim sum (look up and you'll see it!), and in general the taste and food quality is pretty good. Not a bad place to pick up some snacks on the go if you happen to walk past that area.
author: Henry L.

description:
Tiny place with a good amount of seating compared to other fast food dim sum places in Chinatown. The food is mediocre but it's as homemade as it can get. "Homemade leftovers" is a better description. Tastes like my grandmother made it but it's been chilling for a good day; still delicious but the quality isn't amazingly fresh. 
I love how there's a good amount of seating here and each table has condiments available. I love smothering my dim sum in hot sauce and soy sauce. And it's so easy walking over to the front and ordering more food. Another plus is their thai tea! Very satisfying. 3.5/5
author: Kimmy L.

description: Quintessential hole-in-the-wall dim sum. It actually has seating inside and pictures of each item on the menu. Just don't expect a fine dining experience. Come for the dim sum and expect no more.
author: Mike P.

description:
Oh House of Dim Sum, you disappoint me.

Pro: There plenty of tables down and upstairs.

The pro list stops there. I ordered shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, and wonton noodle soup here. The dim sum was cold!!! WTF?!?!?!? Who serves dim sum cold? Omgahh I was so upset. My friend and I had to wait 5 minutes for our wonton noodle soup. My bowl had noodles, but my friend's didn't. By this time we were over this place and didn't care anymore. The wonton noodle soup sucked. There was no flavor in it. The egg custard plates were left out in the open for flies to land on. 2 other friends ordered the fried rice and porridge. Both were very bland.

We had to ask the ladies for everything from napkins to forks to spoons to chopsticks. They handed our food without anything. Isn't it common sense that we'd need utensils?! Did they expected us to eat wonton noodles soup or fried rice with our hands?! 

Don't waste your time here.
author: Wendy H.

description:
It is good for what it is, a cheap and quick dim sum place. The service was not bad. The Chinese lady serving the food was pretty friendly and gave me some good suggestions. The options were rather limited.

Some of the some luke-warm and the egg tart was cold. It didn't have the freshness of a legit dim sum place. But again, keep in mind you're paying next to nothing for "dim sum lite". 

If you're hungry and wants some cheap dim sum, this is the place to go. If you want real dim sum, go some where else.
author: Michael J.

description:
Really inexpensive, large selection, very friendly accommodating waitresses - who stand behind the counter and plate the  selections you point to . 
I gave them  three stars because the lady who served us the hot tea was solicitous - she made sure the kettle of hot water would not slip around on the plastic tray by making it sit on some paper napkins. Small gestures like that are always a nice plus.
Think of a restaurant that has dining seats but is really more of a take-out place.
Hole in the wall, more seating on the upstairs area. 

The fried dumpling is really good - gooey sweet rice (mochi) around a savory meat filling. I thought the pork shu-mai was a tad too swiney tasting , the beef shu-mai was less meaty and had a mealy mouth feel. Har -gow (shrimp) and shrimp with cilantro were better in terms of texture and flavor. 

Lots of dimsum  was constantly being steamed so everything was nice and hot if you arrive for lunch service. The fried selections though came cold since they pretty much just sit on huge trays on the counter. 

We did not eat at the place across the street since they did not seem to have dine-in tables.
author: Joyce A.

description: Avoid. Unequivocally the worst dim sum I've ever had the displeasure of putting in my mouth. The flavors were off, the textures were off, and it wasn't even warm. Had I not been as famished as I was, I would've stood up and walked out after the first bite.
author: Rob L.

description:
2.5 stars

Very cheap dim sum. Most things we ordered (char sui bao, siu mai, chicken and mushroom, and lotus leaf) were pretty tasty. But don't let the Chinese lady at the counter pressure you into ordering other things. She was pushy, and I couldn't understand her English, and she kept insisting we try some other things. One was the har gao (shrimp) and it was HORRIBLE. And because there were two of us, she gave us two orders. Needless to say, that went straight into the trash. 

But overall, for $20 bucks, we had a huge dim sum breakfast and were on our way. Order anything but the har gao, and I think you'll be fine. Its not the greatest dim sum, obviously being a take out place (with two small tables), but if you're in a rush and want something cheap, this place will do it for you...
author: Bella B.

description:
Worst dim sum I've ever had, paired with horrible service. I know Chinese waiters aren't the politest folks, but this was absurd. We really should have just walked out, and if you're reading this post while standing in front of the counter, you should too. 

The dim sum was cold (sitting out on trays) and way too expensive for what it was. Go across the street to Delicious Dim Sum instead. Delicious Dim Sum had a line out the door - we should have picked up on that.
author: Andrea L.

description:
$20 for ha gow, shui mai, him bao, fried rice with two cokes.  The shui mai had been sitting out and the pinch dough on the edge had become dried and hard.  Unedible.  We left half our food uneaten and then departed.  

Avoid this place
author: Scott L.

description:
This place is not meant to be eaten at because the food is good. You eat there because it's there and it's quick.

We got all our favorite dim sum dishes right away, seated ourselves, and finished eating in 20 minutes. I was waiting on an appointment so this a perfect QUICK bite. I would never go again because of the quality. The food is sub par.
author: Hang T.

description: Went in for a quick take out bite. Not the cleanest but pretty authentic. Communication difficulties impeded me getting exactly what I wanted but food was still ok for something on the go. The meats were difficult to differentiate and were a bit mushy and greasy- kind of like baby food. The best was the spicy pork that had water chestnuts in it. However there was no spice and the steamed rice bun was gelatinous and way too thick.
author: Terrell B.

description: House of dim sum? More like house of dim wits! They charged us for things that we never ordered! They were like " No, no, no, you pay now, NOW!" right in the middle of our meal! The food was okay but the service was TERRIBLE and REPULSIVE. NEVER, EVER COME HERE!!!!
author: Nico B.

description:
It's been awhile since I've written a review, but what happened today warrants at least a mention.

So for Chinese New Year, myself and my 3 co-workers decided to get dim sum. We trekked for half a mile (which is long when you're limited on lunch time!). I ordered and paid and walked all the way back to work only to realize that they had forgotten to put half our order in the bag.

I called and explained the situation only to be told that I hadn't paid for the forgotten order! I told them that I had paid $25 and only had a portion of it. They proceeded to have me list all the items that I had in my box and hastily told me to go back and get it.

When I went back an hour later, there was a cold box of food sitting there. No apology, no sense of remorse, rather rude service. I asked if I could get fresh food and was told that everything was out. Everything was not out, but I decided not to argue.

This truly was disappointing and a bit embarrassing since I had finally convinced my usually Chinatown-averse colleagues to join me here :/
author: Suzi F.

description: Worst I've ever had - also $4 for two pcs of shumai and 2 shrimp rolls. They even had to put in microwave versus being freshly steamed.
author: JT H.

description: I've been going here off and on and depending on what you order, the finger food is to take out and just go.  The fried rice and chow mein may be somewhat dried up but, hey, they might just charge you 2 or 3 buck and out you go.  Yeah, they don't necessary cook it in the best manner, but if you're starving on Mars you'll eat anything including the dust bowl.
author: BanBan B.

description:
This place is horrible.  The food is greasy and cold, even after microwaving it!  I only went here because my parents weren't patient enough for me to Yelp better places.  There were actually better places within the next block...

If I was starving, I still wouldn't come to this place.
author: Vira P.

description:
Street dim sum is just so beautiful.

Parking is available on the street.

The inside is quite dated, and who knows how long often the equipment has been cleaned.

The staff were quite chatty, and were gossiping away while we placed our orders.

The dim sum would be of decent quality, but unfortunately we walked in after lunch hour.  In other words, the dim sum was cold.  Try to go earlier in the day.

Definitely not as delicious as Delicious across the street, but still somewhat decent nonetheless.
author: Edward L.

description:
OMG! RIP OFF!!! 
KEEP AWAY!

One piece of chang fun is 2.50!
One small plate of chow mein is 2.50!!!

YIKES!!!
Nice people, restroom and seating upstairs, but still..
NEVER AGAIN!
author: David W.

description:
HORRIBLE...... Enough Said.....
   Don't Say I Didn't Warn You
Worst DimSum I've Ever Had and Pot Stickers Were Old,  Stale and Begged To Be Thrown Away. 
I Took One For The Team
author: Philip G.

description:
We should have taken a hint when this place was quiet during the lunch rush. In any case, we took our chances mostly because we were too lazy to wait in line elsewhere, and we paid for it. I don't even have dim sum that often and I could tell that the food didn't quite taste right. House of Dim Sum fell short in almost every possible way. The flavors were bland, the textures were all wrong, and weird substitute ingredients were often used for traditional dishes. 

The sticky rice I ordered was complete mush but was stiff and hard at the same time. I don't know how they did it either. Actually I do. The odd texture pretty much gave it away: the rice was obviously stale and cooked either the day before (or even earlier) and reheated. The lazy college student version of me has definitely done this before and I'm not proud of it. The egg yolk inside was also uncharacteristically crumbly and synthetically bright which scared me a little. Definitely decided not to finish my meal out of fear. 

I think the topper to all of this disappointment was that the prices did not appropriately reflect the quality. If this place had been dirt cheap, we would have expected the quality of food we received. However, the prices were hardly a bargain and I'm sure there are a multitude of cheaper, better-tasting, good quality dim sum places within just a few blocks. 

Steer clear of this place if you ever find yourself wandering Chinatown, even if you feel like you're in a bind to find a cheap/quick lunch at the last minute. Definitely felt a little ripped off as we left this place since it all came together once we noticed that House of Dim Sum's main customer base seems to be made up of tourists who don't know any better as well. In retrospect, it makes sense that tourists are attracted to this little place that has no line and provides seating. It's perfect for those who need to save time in order to see all the sights but also take a moment to sit and rest their feet from all the walking through the hills of SF.
author: Junes S.

description:
We ate some food here while waiting for Lai Hong to open. It was very bland and there was a fly crawling over our rice. The law muy gai had very little meat and the chow mein is dry. The portions were big, but who cares if the food sucks?

Would not come back here.
author: Margaret F.

description:
I only suggest eating here if you're super hungry and if you do to get the wonton soup it's the only thing worth eating. Other than that I'm sure there's a better place around to eat. 

P.S. I suggest bringing napkins they're a little on the stingy side here.
author: june b.

description:
We were touring Chinatown and decided to grab some dim sum. Without yelping, we picked this place.

Pros: the steamed pork bun was excellent, the woman behind the counter was very friendly (even if she did oversell us pretty hard) and veggie dumplings were yummy.

Cons: the woman behind the counter put more stuff on our plate than we asked for and charged us for them. I think she pretended not to understand English when we tried to tell her we didn't want them.

It was very inexpensive and they have some tables for sitting which is nice. Not the cleanest place in the city, but pretty par for the course for Chinatown.

An hour later my friend had to make an emergency pit stop (if you know what I mean...) but I was totally fine. My stomach is made of iron.

Can't say I'd rush back but I thought it was fine.
author: Rachel E.

description: This place is trash! Dirty, food is oily, employees are super rude and food was not even good. Do not eat here!
author: Claudia A.

description: Had dinner here. Good food for a.good price. You can choose lots of items that are in front of you. They will heat it up in micro wave. The food was tasty. I bought a pork bun two pot stickers two shrimp balls.and a long noodle. It was a good price.
author: Dwight S.

description: Possibly the worst siu mai I've ever tasted. This is also very expensive compared to other competitors. I did not even finish my food and that NEVER happen with dim sum. Won't be back again.
author: Kwoky L.

description: Decent place to grab a QUICK bite. We got a plate full of shrimp dumplings, fried dumplings, soup dumplings, pork and shrimp balls, bbq pork buns, etc. Everything was decent, not the best. It's cheap too. I'd stay away from the boba though, everything is just stored in the fridge in large containers and poured into a cup when ordered.
author: Kristine N.

description: It was a raining day on Sunday and we went to Chinatown for Dim Sum.  Of course, we used Yelp to search for options prior to arrival, and found a few places with great ratings.  Unfortunately, when we got to Chinatown we realized none of these places have seating areas!  Given the weather, we had to settle for this place because it has a dining area.  Well, the ratings were accurate- the food really wasn't that good.  Many of the items were served cold, including the pork buns they took out of the steam tray! It was also strange that my food items were served to me on a thin paper plate, because I didn't have a place to pour soy sauce into for dipping!!  So, I'm giving this place two stars, one for having a dining area, and one for the food server being reasonably friendly... but sorry, no star for the actual food.
author: Sarah W.

description:
I went here yesterday during the Chinese New Year festival. There is limited space for seating inside and I wanted to just get our food to-go and eat elsewhere but my family wanted to sit down so some of us went upstairs to get a table. The only table big enough to seat all of us was taken by a group of people in the corner who weren't even eating. They were just sitting there talking. We ended up sitting at two separate tables. 

I'm assuming that the customers are suppose to be responsible and clean up after themselves because none of the employees ever went upstairs and it was filthy. Most of the tables weren't even cleaned off. Several tables had leftover food and trays on them and there was only one small garbage can in the corner. Since practically all the food was greasy, it soaked through the paper plates and left a pool of grease on the tables. But the mess doesn't bother some people. This old man sat down and just pushed the mess aside and ate his food. 

My aunt was getting frustrated because the lady behind the counter was helping four people at once and didn't even seem to care who got what food. When my aunt tried asking how much the food cost, these little old Chinese women came in and practically pushed her out of the way and started ordering their food. I've seen this kind of behavior in a lot of other places. If you're in the way, they'll move you. If they want something, they'll go for it regardless of who else was there before them. They don't consider themselves rude because in some cultures that's how things are done. I'm used to it but I can see how others would get irritated really fast.

The food was just ok. They didn't serve anything that you couldn't find at the next half dozen dim sum places down the street. If you do want food from here, get it to go because eating here is like being in a pig sty.
author: Bryan L.

description:
Came here early on a Saturday morning looking for a dim sum breakfast.  Was around 8:30 so street parking on Jackson not a problem.  Was between House of Dim Sum and other places on Jackson, decided to give it a try.

Being a shu mai junkie, ordered 9 of those.  Some ha gow, low mei gai, chinese donuts and cha sui bow.

All the dim sum was not bad.  Shu mai a little lacking in flavor but not greasy.  Cha sui bau was huge but the filling was so-so.

Paid over $20 bucks for all this.  Seemed a little high.  The shu mai was $2.25 for an order of 3, most places are $1.50.  For the price, not worth it.  Plus,  I think they charged me the don't-speak-Chinese-tax.

Will continue looking for a good take out dim sum place in SF Chinatown.  House of Dim Sum isn't it.
author: Steve G.

description: Great dim sum take away, but they also have upstairs seating should you want to eat there. Excellent food.
author: Heather D.

description:
It could just be me but I did not have a good experience here. 
I came here on my first day in town. Exhausted and hungry from walking the freaking steepest streets, I just went into the first place that offered me food to satisfy my craving. 
Chinatown is a very special place to be here in the city, it is much different than other parts of SF and definitely lives up to different hygiene standards, or so it seems.
Also this place was in a rather questionable state  (the food just sits there and waits to be bought, without protection or cooling or such thing) but I did not care. 
The woman behind the counter barely spoke English and I tried to tell her what I wanted. Before I could make up my mind she just said "I make plate, one of each?" and in my starving state I nodded.

This may not have been the best idea. The dumplings were cold, I have no idea if this should be this way or not, but talking for myself, I would have expected something warm. 
Unfortunately, I could not find out what kind of filling each dumpling had, it all tasted the same: meaty and greasy. 
The hot sauce saved my meal. I still did not feel that good after my lunch, but again, it could also be due to my lack of experience with Dim Sum and the not westernized asian food.
Unfortunately, I will not go there anymore.
author: Vera H.

description:
Not too expensive
No long waits
Grabbing to go
Hole in the wall joint with ok dim sum.

This is an ok place for dim sum especially if your on the go.
author: T C.

description: This place is surprisingly great. I walked in not expecting much, but I was blown away. The prices are very low for the quality of food you get. Obviously not the absolute best dim sum place in the city, but a great place for those looking for good dim sum on a budget.
author: Sebastian T.

description:
Food itself was pretty good - favorites were chicken feet and red bean buns. Least favorite were dragon dumplings. Reasonable given the price.

Something a little disconcerting is they do not have free drinking water, which I'm pretty sure is required by the state. When I asked for water, lady said I could buy bottled water or boiled water; when she pointed to the tap she told me "but do you think it's clean?" I appreciate the honesty...but I would appreciate some water more!
author: Heather C.

description:
Avoid this place! Went on a hunt for good dim sum in Chinatown and sadly ended up in here. Dim sum was very oily and flavorless. With Delicious Dim Sum right across the street serving more inexpensive and tasty dim sum, there's no reason to come here. 

Everything I ordered tasted... the same. I'm not sure if they're using a type of sauce or ingredient to mask the flavor of the food, but it was just very sub par dim sum. The restaurant itself is also very dark and didn't seem very sanitary. However, I will give them an extra star for having seating upstairs, something that most grab and go dim sum places don't have. Overall, there are just a multitude of better dim sum options in Chinatown that there's no reason to come to this one.
author: Sunny H.

description:
This place isn't exactly horrible. They do have seats to sit! The food is alright, yet nothing too special. The staff tries to be helpful with the orders, but for dim sum the basics should include chicken feet and they don't have it? It's barely 9am when I ordered to dine in. The buns were subpar (I mostly chewed fat instead of the bbq pork I anticipated). I kind of have trouble eating the food... not quite sure how to pinpoint it. It just wasn't appetizing?

Food for the price charge is average, but for the taste it is lacking. 

One other notable thing is the claustrophobic bathroom they have on the second floor. The tables are not sticky but the soy sauce bottles and shakers were caked. I disliked that feeling...
author: Amy T.

description: Just like the rating says: Meh. I've experienced better. Had pork dumplings and turnip cake, three each, $5 total. At least the price wasn't too bad.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Delicious food, great price and they also had vegetarian options :) I would definitely recommend it.
author: Juliet G.

description: I had a craving for some sweet rice cakes so I went to Chinatown. To my surprise, it wasn't easy finding them but at last, House of Dim Sum came to the rescue. Not sure how much they are anywhere else but I bought 6 rice cakes for $4 or something cheap like that. I'll be back.
author: Kat E.

description:
Since I didn't get my dumplings from Good Mong, I stopped at House of Dim Sum (I should have tried Delicious Dim Sum across the street). Service was courteous but the food was not of good quality. I got:

- Shrimp Dumplings: An unpleasant shrimpy aftertaste. Plus there was shrimp shell in the dumpling. 

- Potsticker: Sizable and the filling tasted good but the wrapper was too thick and doughy. It didn't taste quite fresh either. 

Plus, $2.25 for an order of 3 items = highway robbery for Chinatown.
author: Maya S.

description:
If you want to actually sit down and have some dim sum instead of the typical grab and go in the area, this is a good spot. It's definitely a hole in the wall, but every dumpling I've had has been great. 

There are more tables upstairs (that no one seems to know about) so it's a good place to take a break. Be forewarned though, the bathrooms are a little sketch, however I survived so honestly who cares. 

Good cheap dumplings and nice staff.
author: Amy W.

description:
Worst experience ever! I can't beginning to tell you how horrible the dim sum tastes and how expensive it was for what we received. I had a craving for dim sum and wanted a quick bite to eat. I yelped the closest take to go place and walked into the wrong dim sum place. AHHHH!

The dim sum was sitting out all day on the counter not covered and then she microwaved it. Oh Why? Oh why? did we walk in here?! A hole in a wall with food that tastes like crap on the floor. Stale wrapping, shrimp shells in the dumplings, and chewy texture for fillings. We spat the food out, left the rest untouched and just walked out.  

Lesson learned: Always! Always double checked the building address.
author: Alice P.

description:
A little attention to hygiene would do them a lot of good. 

Food: In reality, the food isn't that bad. I grabbed some dan tat (egg custard), sesame balls (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o__w2Hufu0Bdc_hKfi8OYg?select=pmofautJE_UJoks4IqeZQg), veggie dumplings (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o__w2Hufu0Bdc_hKfi8OYg?select=pcKF825Eo76R_iHmvbJQsw), har gow, and sticky rice wrapped in a banana leaf (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o__w2Hufu0Bdc_hKfi8OYg?select=q6wgGQ36Q5A_43WorADjkw) with a friend. Nothing stood out that much and it wasn't as bad as what most people have been reporting. If you were served this food blindly without looking at the kitchen, I'm sure you wouldn't be able to tell the difference between this and most other dim sum joints. 

Atmosphere: Someone please hire a janitor. It is dirty and cramped in here. The Hello Kitty plates help to take off the edge, but even that cannot detract from the grease stained walls and nasty pans used to hold the food. I don't know why I actually stayed to eat after coming in. 

Service: Communication is a little rough with some of the employees. I had to point to everything just to order. They seem nice enough, but like I said before, they are in dire need of janitorial services or a complete renovation. 

Synopsis: So many other options here in Chinatown.
author: Toni L.

description:
Keep in mind this place is cash only. We had  to withdraw cash from an ATM to pay for our meal. The dim sum was delicious, but cold. Our meal was only $12 though and it was enough to feed two people. 

I'm giving this place 3 stars instead of 2 because they were able to accommodate us while the other places across the street were not. There was either no seating or one place tried to tell me you can have "all-you-can eat dim sum" and they had nothing but buns, wonton soup, and fried rice.
author: Sandy Z.

description:
CASH ONLY.  It's just a hole-in-the-wall dim sum shop.  I went there on a weekday around 4pm and they still had some stuff.

I got Sticky rice in lotus wrap $2 ea.  They are Giant, but not that tasty.  Add lots of soy sauce & hot sauce to make it better.

Steamed dumplings - they were cheap, can't remember around $2 something for a bunch.  Tasted ok.
author: Ann L.

description: No frills hole and the wall dim sum to go place.  The dim sum was sub par in my opinion and they charge you for tea.  But if you just want some dim sum quick and don't want to spend too much money, then this is definitely the place for you.
author: Richard L.

description:
A random little 2-story dim sum shop with about a dozen or so fried, steamed, or baked items to select from.  Ordered 6 items and paid about $19.  The only item that was yummy is the steamed shrimp roll...the soft texture of the rice flour skin was exceptional.  The Siu Mai, although hot and fresh (the way I like most things in life...lol), was below average.

You can eat your dim sum in the shop or take it for togo.  Ask for paper plates and plastic utensils if you need them.

Would I come here again? Only if I were hungry for a snack.  Otherwise, I'd rather sit in a nicer dim sum restaurant.  Snob, I know.
author: Lily L.

description:
Just stop here cuz saw some
Lights ... The ladies on from kind of nice service kind of fast... Food is ok no bad jo great... Prices are reasonable .. Lunch for 2 $20 ... With plenty of food
The best for me was pork dumpling...
author: Frenchy G.

description:
This is a hole in the wall type restaurant. The service was quick and friendly. Everything tasted very good, the textures were what was only average. We paid about $18 for enough dim sum to make us quite full, so I think House of Dim Sum offers a good value, especially when compared to Yank Sing where I paid $60 for two. 

The har how was slightly mushy but tasted fine. Wor tip skin was very chewy but that's how I like it. Shu mai didn't look as delicious as at some other places but taste and texture were good. The Dan tarte were perfect - strong egg flavor and flaky, non greasy crust.
author: David H.

description:
I can tell that this place has been here for years because everything seemed old, but it is well loved and clean. No sticky counters, glass, or windows. the ladies behind the counter are always really helpful and nice, and patient. 

I think the dim sum is a little pricey, and all the products a little more doughy than other places will make it. 

I choose to come here when I'm being lazy, and don't want to walk the extra 3 blocks to my favorite to go dim sum place.
author: Vicky L.

description:
There is additional seating upstairs. One of the few dim sum places with seating available. The food was fair, but can get a little pricey. 

Ordered three of those shrimp rolls- $9. 

The food is prepared and sits in front of the restaurant. 

The lady was nice- chatted with her for a bit. The food was fair, still better than what San Diego can offer, but not LA. 

Fresh eggtart was yummy.
author: Wenny W.

description: Warning-Do not use the restroom or you will lose your appetite. That being said, the dim sum is good. The two  of us ate for lunch for $12.50. Both stuffed. Love the shrimp filled steamed dumplings. Good place for a quick lunch.
author: Joe M.

description: Lots of food was cold since it sits out. The dim sum was cheap, but not very good. I'd recommend skipping this place for another dim sum restaurant (loads in the area)
author: Roger S.

description: I'm from Orange County where there's pretty authentic Asian food. This was my first time in China town and it was unfortunate we chose to eat here. Food is either bland or taste gross. We ordered a variety of dim sum items and the wonton soup, not a single thing was good. I'm extremely disappointed and disgusted with this place. The ladies up at the front are also rude and act annoyed at people ordering and giving them money... DO NOT EAT here!!!!!
author: juliet T.

description:
I wanted some dimsum and saw this place! I went in, and the lady was nice, smiled and all, but she obviously wanted me to purchase the fried shrimp dumpling and other things! Lady, I said no! LOL.  I ordered lo mai gai (1), ha gao (2), sesame balls (3), ham siu gok (1) and cha siu bao (1). Before ordering the cha siu bao, I asked if it was hot. The lady said yes, so I ordered one. When I walked out of the place and touched the bao, it was not hot. It was room temp. -__-;;;;;; At least the woman at the Asian bakery a couple blocks down was nice enough to tell me that the bao that I wanted would be cold! Ai yah! 

Anyway, I was very excited for everything else that I ordered. However, when I ate the sesame ball, I was not pleased. The glutinous part was more on the bland side, which was a disappointment. I proceeded to eat the ham siu gok...the meat was more on the mushy side. D: wei shenme?! 

I was looking forward to the lo mai gai more than anything, so I steamed, unwrapped and stuck my fork into it! Is it supposed to be, dare I say, a bit bitter? D': The meat was like the ham siu gok, mushy texture. TT__TT  Mushy, as in...not like the ground beef that you have in Tacos...mushy like it has already been chewed up for you. 

The ha gao were ok. They were smaller than the usual ones that I see around.

My purchase came down to be $7 flat.  

By the way, milk tea with boba is $3. I asked, because I was curious.

Overall...no. Never again. I'm not picky about my food. Just make them edible, and bare-able then it's cool. But no. Not this place, please.
author: Janet T.

description: Food was cold like it just came out of the fridge and it was way over priced, when we ask the lady to take our food back, she just reheat it in the microwave and brought it back to us, we will never go back there again for cold overpriced food served on a paper plate, look dirty.
author: Karen B.

description:
Very greasy. Very. Greasiest dim sum I've ever had. It's all very tasty, but oily. What in the world do you guys do, use fat/lard as an ingredient? You soak everything in lard? The xia long bao and siu mai is some of the greasiet I've ever had!  There is chunks of congeled fat in the har gow. I feel like I now need to drink an entire gallon of hot tea or alcohol just to combat all of the grease.

House is well over priced as well, but Delicious Dim Sum was closed. Paid $15 for the same order I usually pay about $8 - $10 at Delicious. Dim Sum is supposed to be cheap, especially in Chinatown.

The items were okay, but you could do better taste wise and price wise by checking out others in Chinatown or in the Rimond district, if you're out that way.
author: Sheba B.

description: Not sure it is because it is now almost 7 and no more customers. All of my dim sums are dried like paper, the spare ribs only greasy with no taste.
author: Sweetie Joanna A.

description: I'm not sure why this place has so few stars - I stumbled in here on Chinese New Year after seeing Delicious Dim Sum was closed (and good for them!), and loved the helpful picture menu and quick service. As with most places around, super cheap, and the quality of what I got (spinach dumplings, turnip cake, lotus and red bean buns, a sesame ball, and a spongey cup cake) was great. Some of what I wanted was gone by noon (taro things, egg tart (this is an occasional allowance from my veganism!)), so I may arrive earlier next time. This may be the beginning of an obsession...
author: Shendi X.

description: I can't comment on the quality of the dim sum, but we did stop in here for a boba and were disappointed. The line is short yet still slow, and the woman at the counter was rather unpleasant. Our milk tea was super saccharine to the point of being undrinkable, and the boba seemed stale and tasted a little off. If that's the kind of disregard they take toward the beverages, I'd be somewhat cautious toward the food.
author: Micki B.

description: It is very bad, never had dim sum that taste this bad.  And the service is nonexistent, and the sanitation is close to none. Overall there is nothing good about this place, except the cheap price. I would give zero star if that is an option on yelp.
author: Leon C.

description:
DANG!? not even THREE STARS?!?!? 


I guess i'm the only one the truly enjoys their dimsum! I mean honestly, YES their dimsum IS NOT the greatest i've ever had. But, it's all hot and fresh! 

I do have the advantage / upper hand because i speak cantonese, which makes the ordering and communication so much easier, but of course if you only speak english, PLEASE bare with them since they are not english language speakers and theyre were born and raised in homeland china (no excuse, i know, its america, blah blah blah)

their egg tarts? not the best. I'd hope over to golden gate bakery a few blocks away (about 1.5) over on Grant ave to grab some. But, some shrimp dumplings and the banana leaf sticky rice, ALL IN BABY! HAND ME THAT GOODNESS! 

fair warning: This is still the spot to go! please Ignore the huge spot across the street and do not go there, they serve some crappy dim sum that isn't fresh at all
author: Kenny L.

description:
Apparently we made the same mistake as everyone else.  Our excuse is that we had hungry kids and needed to have a place to sit.  Plus I thought I would try to go Yelpless. The kids ate it so it must have been okay cause they are not that adventurous.  

I ordered a variety of different things and nothing really stood out.  I almost broke my tooth on the lo mein.  The shu mai was decent.  The place was really dirty feeling and it reflected upon the food so I understand why the better dim sums are "to go".
author: Joe S.

description:
COLD. Cheap tasting. Not good.

I'm currently sitting in here and feeling gross after my meal. I should've just gone to McDonald's or something. I'm Vietnamese and some of the food items I was familiar with and it was really nothing special. 

They have bubble tea and I can see the already prepared ones in the fridge. Meaning it isn't fresh. The cooked food lays on the counter for hours. None of the food is fresh. 
And since they have the door open. The food gets cold, quick.
author: Jessica B.

description: I needed a quick breakfast so I stopped here on my way to run some errands. Service was quick as everything was premade. Ordered a few har gau and siu mai. Har gau was something left to be desired, barely had any shrimp and the skin was coming off completely. Siu mai was decent. It was pretty chilly that morning so I got a bowl of juk as well. Consistency was good, but lacked flavor. The pi dan was standard but the pork had no taste, green onions would have been nice too. With so many other dim sum places, i don't think I will be heading back to this one.
author: Dennis L.

description:
I would give ZERO stars if it were an option. Tourists beware! They charge you higher prices and your ignorant happy arse won't know any better unless...you read this: 

I went in with my mom and sister on a late afternoon. There were flies on the pork shu mai. The floor was sticky and squeaky. The dim sum was greasy and cold. We were charged $27 for three waters, some shu mai, one pork bun, and that's about it. 

We sit and eat. A local comes in to shake the day off him, orders similar to us (no water) and pays $4.50. They can charge whatever they want because there are no prices.

I walked out fuming. This place is a rip off! But is aptly as it is the house of dim sums.
author: Suzi P.

description:
Its a small hole-in-the-wall, mostly for take out but they have 3 or 4 tables where you can sit and eat. I used to the cart ladies with dim sum restaurant but here you order like a Chinese buffet where all the food is on display. 

One nice thing for non-chinese and dim sum beginners is that they have a large menu posted on the wall with prices, names and pictures. Its a down and dirty place and not for the "A" graded restaurant eaters, but if you like dim sum and you're not a princess then its definitely worth it.
