The prices are very good, I fed a family of four for $16.
author: Owen I.

description: So so. We were really hungry and the better rated dim sum restaurants either had no tables or the line was too long.
author: Dan T.

description:
The lady behind the counter didn't seem to like that I was Asian but spoke no Mandarin/Cantonese, but she was helpful enough. I am a pescatarian, so I asked for something that only had shrimp - she pointed out the shrimp rice roll things. I also got a turnip cake.

It was a bit greasy, but pretty delicious. The turnip cake just melted in my mouth.

Next time I'm in SF, I'll be back!
author: Thao N.

description: The dim sum here is decent. They have a pretty good selection of different kinds. The shrimp dumplings are probably my favorite. Most dumplings are $0.75 each and you can do take out. The steamed pork or chicken buns are yummy. This is a good place to quickly stop in and grab a little bit a dim sum for the road.
author: Kathy A.

description: This place was my first taste of dim sum in San Fran and I was disappointed. Nothing I got tasted fresh (ie buns were stale), they were out of a bunch of things as well...I got the feeling that the dim sum sits there all day.
author: Sabrina J.

description: The only thing I've ever had here is the beef rice crepe roll. It's pretty good. 3 stars at least. Mostly Chinese in here. That's a pretty good sign.
author: Brian J.

description: Dim Sum was tasty... Ordered siu mai was tasty. The place its self is old and very shabby. If you didn't know they had an upstairs you would think you have to take your order to go. The upstairs is even more dank. Last looks dirty. Cave like...no lights on. I guess that could be a good thing. You can't see the dirt.
author: Hollis W.

description: Okay, so we're wandering the streets in search of a snack that my mother will eat. She doesn't do Chinese food :( silly lady. And I spot the House of Dim Sum across the street. Running over and peeking in I see a load of goodness. We shared barbecue pork buns - sweet and doughy with a slightly salty/oniony pork goodness inside. Each of us had an egg custard tart that melted in our mouths - so nice. And lastly we shared an order of the pork/veggie dumplings. These were seasoned and cooked to perfection. This spot is a hole in the wall, literally. But who cares? Good food can be found anywhere and I'm glad we found this place for an afternoon snack.
author: Deb S.

description: Craving Dim Sum and forgot that today is Wednesday and my go-to spot DDS is closed.  Friendly woman at the counter and plenty of selections and the good sign of Chinese patrons sitting at tables.  Bland, weird tasting dim sum, I ate one piece, then two.  I tossed the rest of what I bought when I tasted the distinct flavor of moldly in the food (piece two).  Glad I stopped for some veggie noodles elsewhere as a side.  I won't be coming back.
author: Donna H.

description: Ran out of noodles at lunch time.  They had to micro the plate they did give us.  Blah
author: Stuart K.

description:
it's a 3 stars restaurant and cash only. if u want tea, u gotta pay for it! lol
i think the food is alright....it's decent but it's def not the best and i'm not sure about the freshness because they had to microwave some of our food when we order. they could have done a better job keeping it moist and warm :/ the ladies were nice though, but i don't think i'd want to go back unless im super hungry and that's the only place available -_-
author: Ru C.

description: Flavourless food. Had to walk out without finishing. I had the congee and Chinese donut. Both were put in the microwave before given to me. I should have known this place was going to be bad by the sheer look of the place. I, for one, love whole in the wall places, however,  this place is dirty looking. Even the pepper shaker was empty.
author: Jen M.

description: WOW!  WOW! WOW WOW!  Seriously?  Amazing little clouds of bbq pork that just melt into your mouth wanting more.  So delicious, that you just eat them on the go, while walking around the fabulous Chinatown.  I went back and bought some to bring home.  Oh what a buck can do!  This is the first place I'll go to when ever I go back to San Francisco.  :)  Remembering the taste brings a smile to my face :)
author: A M.

description: Actually, we wanted to go to Delicious Dim Sum, but there was no table available at that time. That's why we ended up with this because it's just across the street. The ladies serving food were so rude to me. One of them didn't even hear what I was saying - I just tried to figure out how I can make an order! The shrimp and pork something dim sums are good, but not warm enough... I strongly recommend you to take your time to wait for a table in the restaurants with great reviews.
author: Alicia K.

description: Ok dim sum at best. The customer service and cleanliness is terrible. Prices are ok but the lady wore the same gloves to take money, serve food and clean up. Wont come back.
author: R N.

description:
The dim sum is pretty decent, didn't wow me and to be honest I don't remember what I ate.   On the plus side service is fast and prices are rock bottom.  

People who are complaining about the friendliness of service need a crash course in Chinese culture.
author: Roger H.

description: The worse!!!! Cold food in this resutrant!! Worse service ever!! Really really bad attitude toward the costumes!! There is a Chinese Woman being so rude!! I am Chinese but she seems to hate life n work there. Never want to go there again! I will give zero star if I can.
author: Penny L.

description:
Very good Malay cake or "ma lai gao"!

This is where my aunties and uncles go for their malay cake in C-town. It's a typical take-out dim sum place in Chinatown. There are many locations like this in the neighborhood so competition must be pretty stiff but most places can distinguish themselves with a few quality items which outshine their competition. 

The malay cake here is light, spongy, eggy and not too sweet. And, each piece is only $0.65! I've tried the other dim sum items on the menu and everything is alright...I would go back again but only if convenient.

I would make a special trip for the malay cake here though!
author: Lisa M.

description: Awful!   I would rate this no star.  Found a bug on my hard steamed pork bun.  Waste of money even a bum wouldn't take my left overs.
author: Ann A.

description: This place is just ok - the price was ok, the food was ok, tge service was ok. But i bet there are restaurants with much more tastier dim-sum around and even across the street.
author: David B.

description:
Dern it, I meant to go to Delicious Dim Sum up the street. Totally spaced out. Food here was average, service was friendly. I like the shrimp dumplings.

16 shrimp dumplings + 1 sesame ball = $10.75. And this critic's belly is full.
author: Andrew W.

description: First time in SF's Chinatown so dim sum was on my agenda. This place had quite a selection. The best thing I tried was the cilantro shrimp.  Worst choice was the chow mein.  Doesn't seem appealing when they have to zap it in the microwave (in front of you).  By the time I got to it on my plate, it had gotten cold/hard so I left most of it. Also the flimsy paper plates weren't a big hit, since some of the things I was putting on my plate were quite heavy and moist. The place did have frequent customers, which should be a good sign, but I'm rating it an OK only.
author: Nancy G.

description:
I was in town to run the SF Half, and a friend recommended I go to the dim sum place across the street. Since it was just take out and I need to sit down after running 13.1 and walking around the city after...

I wandered in, sidled up to the counter, and was asked what I wanted. I basically took a sample of many things (except pork), ending up without about 10 pieces of dim sum, a sesame ball and a custard piled on a Hello Kitty plate. Through in a green tea and I'm all set for under $10.

Now, you might think that's pricey, and perhaps it is. Compared to what I have to pay in Texas, it's cheap. I inhaled all of the dim sum, took the desserts (later eating them outside of Coit Tower) and a coconut bubble tea to go (another $2.50), and left with a satisfying feeling in my belly.

If there are better places at a similar price in Chinatown, I'd be interested in knowing for my next trip. For this visit, though, House of Dim Sum delivered.
author: William B.

description: Awesome dumplings. The facility could be cleaner, however the food is great (and affordable) and the people were very friendly.
author: Kathryn Y.

description:
This place does not even deserve one star. I can't believe it is still open for business. Like everyone said, the woman heated up our food in a microwave. I didn't know if this was normal or not, but I ate the shitty dim sum anyway. I ate the "food" hours ago and I still have an upset stomach. I felt nauseated and sick. I still feel like barfing. I think it is definitely not clean at this establishment and the reason why I feel so sick to the stomach is because the food was probably laying out for hours. I am truly shocked at how dirty the dim sum tasted.

One of the worst dim sum experience I've ever had. PLEASE AVOID THIS PLACE AT ALL COSTS. Can't wait to barf out this food tonight.

By the way, hole-in-the-wall establishments usually make up for their lack of decor and cleanliness by delicious tasting food.. but this place was definitely a MISS. 

Gross.
author: Jennie K.

description:
I have a job nearby and am gradually working my way through all the local dim sum houses. 

I've gotten dim sum twice here -once around 10a and once around 2p. Both times the food was so awful I threw it away after taking a bite out of everything trying to find something edible. Not going back.
author: Amy T.

description:
I actually came here thinking it was Yong Kee, which is across the street. Duh.  I'm eating my dim sum as I write. 

The har gao has a funny taste and not in a fun, trippy way.  I'm left wondering if that rumble in my belly is a sign of bad things to come.  Or go, depending on your point of view.

Siu mai is a bit fatty but I like pork fat, so this doesn't bother me.  It's a lot better than the har gao.

Har cheurng is okay; the rice crepe is thicker than I'm used to but not horribly so.  

I also got some gai bao (chicken bun) that aren't bad. The bao part is thicker and denser than I like.  The filling isn't chunky with chicken, it looks like it was pureed and then cooked, which isn't bad but also not really to my taste. 

My advice: skip the har gao (really, skip it), go easy on the har cheurng and gai bao, and buy more siu mai. And it looks like you have to ask for the accompanying sauces for the dim sum.  I brought my order back to my hotel and discovered this the hard way.  I've definitely had better.
author: Lotus B.

description:
Nasty gloves the ladies used to serve your food with.
They don't change their gloves after touching money
and other Yelpers are right about them using microwave 
to heat up your order.

To sum it up, go across the street to Deliclous Dim Sum (that is the correct spelling... I know)

I threw away my order when I got home and ate what I bought from Deliclous Dim Sum.
author: Joseph V.

description:
The first time I went here, it was late in the day on the day on the day of the Chinese New Year parade. Somehow I stumbled upon this place and decided it would be a good idea to order some har gow (shrimp dumplings). Bad idea. They were cold, tough, and the shrimp tasted funny. However, I chalked that up to it being the end of the day. Had I reviewed then, I might have given them three stars.

But not after today, when I visited at 11:30. For whatever reason, I decided to give them another shot. They had spinach dumplings. I asked for six. In the few seconds I spent looking away, the woman behind the counter packed them up. I had been looking at the menu, which said they had sticky rice with chicken, so I got one of those as well. I was charged what seemed like a lot ($6.30) for what little I ordered--the prices were not listed anywhere--and left for work.

Imagine my surprise when I opened up my bag and found six SHRIMP not spinach dumplings. Even more frustrating was that the sticky rice had pork and sausage (two things I don't eat) instead of the chicken I had ordered. The dumplings weren't much better than the previous time, and what little rice I could pick out from around the pork was decent. 

With so many stellar dim sum places in this city, I'm never ever going to return to House of Dim Sum.
author: Katie I.

description:
They microwave their food. Ate off hello kitty plates. The lady kept me interrupting me as I was ordering to talk to a friend who walked in. The food was crap and dry. I was upset, I could get better food at a delivery place in Wisconsin. Bullshit! Little Italy pwned Chinatown. And House of Dim Sum, you're nasty, wipe down your tables, dust, learn to take your customers seriously, and make your food fresh. Dim Sum is a great commodity, and you suck at it.  OH AND BRING CASH! NO CARDS OR CHECKS. Who the hell doesn't have a shit cheap cc machine. Lame.

WISH THERE WAS A RUN THE FUCK AWAY STAR
author: Amanda D.

description:
Cleanliness: nope (minus one star)
Ambiance: nope (minus one star)
Overall Quality: eh, not really (minus one star)
Prices: not bad at all (plus one star)
Steamed pork buns: HELL YEA!  (PLUS FIVE STARS) This steamed pork buns here are on point.  They are delicious and so cheap, just 60 cents each.  I tried one, went home with four the other day.  Finished those, and came back again today and bought a dozen.  

I can't really comment about any of the other dim sum here, but the steamed pork buns rock my world.
author: Vivian L.

description: I love this hole in the wall dim sum place.  It's a good place to stop if you are traveling on a budget and want to try some of the local fare.  My favorites are the steamed pork buns and the sponge cake.  They have a menu board with pictures and English now, which is a plus.  In years past, we used to point at anything that looked good and hope for the best.  Sometimes you end up with something you may not have initially wanted due to an occasional language barrier, but that's part of the fun!
author: Sandra J.

description: Not an expert in Dim Sum but they were very good and inexpensive! We tried about 10 different ones and all good and fresh made!
author: Mariana S.

description:
The service here is horrible... There was one worker who got very impatient with a caucasian customer. I'm not positive if they were lost in translation, but every worker should remain tolerant. It's their job. 
The food wasnt all too bad. It could've been better. Most likely because it wasn't fresh, and it was microwaved. They accept cash only. So keep that in mind. They also served my food on a hello kitty plate. That, I didnt mind. But it was very home-oriented. The restaurant can have better hygiene... I'm not that picky when it comes to food, so keep that in mind. The food wasnt BAD. I've just tasted better.
author: Bianca T.

description:
Wish I could give NO STAR for this review.

This was one of those meals where I wanted to douse myself in Lysol -- my hands, the insides of my mouth, the lining of my esophagus and stomach.

We were getting desperate for a place and truly ended up in here because it seemed okay, and there were several people eating on the first floor.  How bad could it be, right?  I wish I never knew the answer.

Upon entering it looks dingy and dirty, but hey it's a little hole in the wall in Chinatown, I wasn't expecting it to look fancy.

The food looked okay.  We ordered up several items, which the woman put on plastic Hello Kitty plates.  That I could even deal with.  I thought she was going to stick it in a steamer or something.  Instead, she stuck the plates in a microwave.  A f*cking microwave.  I have never, ever had nuked dim sum before.

The shumai and dumplings were okay, although the wrappers were chewy because duh, that's how starch gets when you nuke it.

I took one bite of the chicken humbao and gagged.  It tasted bad, it had weird chunks, and it sure didn't taste chicken-y.  My daughter spit out weird gristly chunks from hers.  Needless to say we didn't eat the rest of the chicken humbao.

We ate upstairs, in a room that looked like no surface had been wiped down for about 20 years.  Every single surface -- table, chair, walls, floor -- was covered in a layer of sticky old grease and the dust stuck in the grease.  It was disgusting.

The food was cheap, like $25 for two platters.  But seeing as we left half of it uneaten because it tasted bad, was too chewy, or was too gross, doesn't make it a great deal after all.

Dim sum is one of my favorite things and I have had it in many restaurants, and this place does not qualify to call itself House of Dim Sum.  Where is the health inspector?  This place would be shut down in a blink.  I wouldn't even call it a restaurant.
author: Myriam G.

description:
I was both disappointed and embarrassed to have taken my dim sum virgin friend to this place. The dim sum that we ordered was warmed up in a microwave...I was shocked, especially when I sat down to eat it as it was luke warm. We were served on the cheapest paper plates that started falling apart after we put the "mystery sauce" on our plates. The sauce consisted of soy sauce and chili paste. The lady who helped us could barely speak English so we weren't sure what we got on our plates.

If you want to eat on a budget go here but don't expect good dim sum. I hope my friend can give me a second chance to show her what real dim sum tastes like.
author: Kaila J.

description:
ugh. 
another disappointing "dim sum" place in SF.  Premade dim sum that was heated up in a microwave, put on paper plates (the really really thin kind, that even doubling, will still leak). And it was overpriced. Seriously, i have nothing more to say. i'm still very upset that i was led here by fellow yelpers.
author: mei s.

description:
Who else write a review for a dim sum place than tourists people? If I am a local guy and I know a good restaurant, why do I bother yelp a place and write a comment? So here we are, tourists looking for a dim sum place on Sunday morning. After searching for 30' a parking place nearby, we ended up at this place (not our first choice). Mistake. We ordered some dim sum and the food was cold. Fried veggie noodles cold. Not sure that the food is fresh or is frozen. We yelped a dim sum place and the one that got the best rating was Delicious Dim Sum place but not sure that we have chosen this place anyway.
My 2cent advise, ask a local guy for a good dim sum place instead of yelp. If you can understand them, you can probably end up at a better place.
author: Lionel T.

description: The Dim Sum here is very expensive compared to other Dim Sum places, also, the Dim Sum here sucks and they sold me food that  tasted sour which means the food is bad already!!! I took a bite and threw the rest away!!!!!  Horrible experience!
author: Christine C.

description:
(more of 3.5 stars)

I order a lot of food in general to efficiently cover multiple meals on 1 trip.

Came here and had the preserved duck leg on rice and some cabbage. And that just can't go wrong.

Also ordered a bunch of dim sum (2 sweet sesame rolls, 2 rice rolls with big shrimps, 3 deep fried "salt water dumplings", 1 deep fried dough, and 2 egg custards.)

All of of this is only $13.15. Food is actually pretty good taste.

No decorations like most Chinese places in this hood but I am not eating the ambiance. Service is very fast.
author: T L.

description:
Yes, the interior is dirty but, that is not the reason why I am slamming this affordable Dim Sum restaurant.  For $10, you can eat quite a lot of dim sum for two people.

In the past, it had been owned under different management and had been well known, a few years back for it's good quality at affordable prices.

Now, everything's changed, and, for the worse.  The dumplings are not hot like they used to be, but, a regrettable luke warm.  That is especially bad for the "steamed" pork buns.

The Jasmine tea was a little good, but the experience wasn't very good.  When I arrived there, I had to use the restroom which I ran in to use prior to purchasing my food.  Because someone spent 3 minutes in the restroom, I waited impatiently.  During that time, the rude woman who worked here gave my friend an attitude implying that we were wasting her time just so that I could use the restroom and leave without paying for anything.

That only made their rating go from a two star place to a one star place which breaks down as follows:

1.  Cold Dim Sum
2.  Dirty inside
3.  and a staff with attitude.

As they say in baseball: three strikes and you're out!

Don't waste your time here when there is better Dim Sum in a very competitive SF Chinatown.  The one's on Stockton Street are better.
author: Tony U.

description: I came here with a friend for a quick grab and go dumplings, and just being in the restaurant made me fell dirty. The dumplings aren't great at all! I tried multiple different stuffings, and I can now say I won't be returning...
author: Erik M.

description: Not bad for some cheap dim sum in China Town. Havent had dim sum in years and the food here hit the spot. Place was dirty as s*** though.
author: Chantelle A.

description:
Showed up at 3 pm.  Small selection of dim sum items, and after we picked what we wanted they put it onto plastic hello kitty plates and threw them into the microwave to heat them up.  Quality was pretty much junk, service was non-existent, and the eating situation was...horrible.

Don't go here.  The whole street is lined with places serving Dim Sum.
author: V L.

description:
SOOO many dim sum places to choose from in Chinatown, we just decided to come in to the next one we walk up to.  So we come in to House of Dim Sum.  I immediately think to myself that I shouldn't expect a whole lot as far as tidyness, super cleanliness, etc that you expect at normal, American restaurants.  I mean, Chinatown is pretty legit Chinese, right? 

So we come in, choose what we want that looks somewhat appetizing...but what's up with the MICROWAVE? You serve me dim sum in weak ass paper plates that are at the cheap end at the 99 cents store!!  I get some soy sauce and chili sauce together in the paper plate to dip my dim sum in, and the plate is falling apart! You may as well have served dim sum to me on a piece of paper. 

The sticky rice was weak. The shrimp and pork dim sum was not bad. There wasn't anything good that stuck out in my mind that would make me want to go back again, because I would definitely not go back there again. I may have gotten a better pork dim sum/shu-mai from a box at trader joe's.  Oh well, until next time I venture out at Chinatown, I'll try to score some good dim sum. I'm open to suggestions.
author: Angeline E.

description:
First off, they use the same blue gloves to serve your food and take your money away.  That is just disgusting!

Second, microwave versus steam?  Steam, all the way.  

Third, flimsy paper plates handled with the same blue gloves.  

Fourth, you're still reading this?

Find another dim sum place.
author: R J.

description:
I went here today. 

For a preserved egg and pork porridge, sprite and 2 loong rice noodles with shrimp, it came out to about $6.50. That's a pretty damn good price since other places around the area charge about 8 bucks!

The lady who was putting my food into containers kept calling me "laang jai" or pretty boy hahaha It's always good to be called that if you're a guy. It just means you look good. Well, they only call you that if you're Chinese. 

Pretty welcoming when you walk in, they even have photos on the wall in case you don't know what the heck you want. 

Overall: 4 stars since I was on the run for lion dance.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
house of dim sum has been around awhile. they offer a few tables for sitdown if one desires to sit.

they sell boba drinks and congee(2ish) also

sampling(around 10:30 am):
-siu mai(3/1.40?) ground pork a little gristly with a whole small shrimp within, tasty but a tad salty.
-har gaw(3/1.40?) tasty pieces of shrimps
-steamed pork bun(1/.60?) big doughy bun, nice amount of filling.
-stameed chicken bun (1/.60?)medium doughy bun, nice moist chicken filling not dry. 
                                                 =4.00, no tax

leftovers
-some msg used.
-pictures of dim sum posted on wall, no prices.
-busy crowd for one server, elderly women ordering boba drinks here.
-don't go too early, they seem to recycle their unsold inventory.
-efficient, friendly service, but they had no change for a $20.
-no frills, no guarantees, do you feel lucky today?
author: Victor G.

description: Ordered 4 pork siu mai for $2.40. I think the lady ripped me off. I just wanted the siu mai so badly (because I haven't had any in a while) but it was just not worth it. The siu mai had like a chunk of fat in it and was very chewy. Nothing to rave about this place.
author: Kathy W.

description:
Oh what could've been...

I love Chinese food. I walked the streets of Xiamen, China with a squid on a stick during the dragon boat festival, and I've never been happier. I couldn't contain my excitement at going to Chinatown, and that my friends is what killed us. Rather than research good Dim Sum, we jumped right in to the first one we found, and we suffered for it.

The lady working didn't listen. Not didn't understand, had great English, and I knew enough Chinese to order, just didn't listen. Put things on our plate we didn't want, gave us a huge plate of whatever she was in the mood for, and refused to give me something I asked for specifically.

Of course this would've been not a big deal if the food hadn't been so awful. Not sure what they seasoned with or if they even did, but everything had a funky flavor to it. Not much variety either, just 5 different variations on shrimp and spinach.

Avoid at all costs. Find another Dim Sum place, there's a LOT of alternatives.
author: Jake O.

description: hole in the wall, cheap. i tried the pork dumplings and chicken feet. both were delicious.
author: Xavier E.

description: While waiting for a table next door at Great Eastern, we killed some time with some food here at House of Dim Sum. We just got some noa my fan (sticky rice with minced pork wrapped in lotus leaf). It was okay. The pork was way too fatty and it was too oily overall. It was really cheap (I think it cost a couple buck for 4 pieces). It was nice to catch some shelter from the rain, and they were nice enough to let us occupy a table for 20 min or so, but this is strictly a kill some time while waiting for better dim sum type of place.
author: Pete V.

description:
In their defense, we were there quite late in the afternoon.

The food was not that much worse than average, but it had been sitting there for a long time and that pushed it over the edge. Seeing the food for the people ahead of us warmed up in the microwave should've given us a hint.
author: Habibi S.

description:
Abominable. To answer Meryl Q's question: because the food sucks?

Eating at this place immediately made me regret that I didn't go to Clement Street upon my first bite.

The pork bao was unrecognizable. The meat was a mushy-textured pinkish/rose color. While we ordered a plate of the pork spareribs, we didn't even bother to eat it, when we saw that one of them was a bit undercooked.

All-in-all we hardly even ate half the food we ordered, despite our hunger. 

After walking out, we felt somewhat upset: a waste not only of money and calories, but it ruined the pleasant ritual of being able to share a good meal with a friend. 

And as the other reviewers have stated, the paper plates that they give you just get soaked through. What you're left eating off is a soy sauce stained, greasy, oilskin smear on the table top. But perhaps even better, the soy sauce at our table looked rancid.
author: Tak N.

description:
Walking into this place I was very tempted to walk back out.  With a name like House of Dim Sum, I was thinking of this multi-leveled haven with tables of people surrounded by plates of dim sum while carts of bamboo steamers are being pushed around for customers to devour.

Or, maybe I'm thinking of another place in Chinatown? 

This place was a little less intense than my fantasy.  A few tables and a woman behind a glass counter with a couple of big metal steamers.  Fine, let's try it.

We asked her to give us a couple of everything which we thought was a great idea until we ended up with a tower of dim sum. Oops.  There were simple condiments: soy sauce and chili oil, but that's all it needed.  Everything on our plate was tasty and fortunately, we were able to get through the entire plate.  Price for dinner? $14... can't beat that. 

It may not be the best place for dim sum in SF, but I enjoyed that kind of "street food" feel.  For first-timers in SF, this is definitely a better option for a taste of San Francisco than eating warm shrimp cocktail on Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Angie M.

description:
What happened to this place?  I've always thought dim sum should be served freshly steamed...not nuked in the microwave for a few seconds.  Is that too mush to ask for?

I've been a patron for years, but the new owners...they suck.  It must be about 10 years ago with the lady with the albino spot on her hair, that was the best years of this place.

It all went downhill after that.  So to House of Dim Sum...I bid farewell.  I will cherish my past memories of this place, and will not forget how you had first set the bar for delicious dim sum. But to this...no more.  Good luck, and may you continue to prosper.  Just not with me anymore  :(
author: Renee V.

description:
We were in Chinatown, it's 4 PM and we were craving for Dim Sum. 
So I yelped a couple of dim sum all day places and found this one. 
It was like a Dim Sum with fast food concept. You come in, pick what you want and pay. 

I guess it kinda tasted bad cause it was already 4. The shells were too hard, the buns are not fluffy, oh but the siomay wasn't bad at all!

Must come back around 11 AM for sure! or even earlier.
author: Miss C.

description:
In my search for that elusive "best dim sum counter in Chinatown," I stumbled across the worst...

When I ordered pot stickers, the girl behind the counter proceeded to pick them up by hand and then threw them in the microwave for a minute. WTF? They can't be steamed like at every other joint in the neighborhood? My white ass can work a microwave!!!

Hard, rubbery nastiness on a flimsy paper plate...
author: Nathan W.

description:
I had the worst shu mai ever, hands down, on the day I made the mistake of trying to visit delicious dim sum on a wednesday and came here instead.

The rest of the dim sum items ranged from unappetizing to mediocre, but the shu mai (something that's pretty hard to screw up) was pretty much inedible.
author: ErUta N.

description: Janelle and Katelyn worked Wondercon last year and found this place and made many returns trips. It is, kindly put, short on ambiance: basically a line of steam trays from which the food is served cafeteria style. I'd heard the girls rave about the baked pork buns as being the stuff of drool-soaked dreams. They ain't wrong: sweet, radioactive red filling in what is a very light and airy dinner roll, glazed with honey. It's basically a dessert with a bit of protein in it. The steamed pork dumplings are very good, as is the shrimp wonton soup which comes from the back, made to order. Also important here: this place is dirt cheap. Loria and I eat for $15, and the food is substantial enough that our 4pm meal holds us for the rest of the day.
author: Ryan C.

description: Just walked in, under the assumption that any place in the area would be good. We didn't get to select our dumplings, the lady tried to over serve us, and it was just a big of a clusterfuck. Plus, my plate and teacup were dirty/greasy, and the flavors were very subdued overall. I would have expected much better seeing as the clientele was a good mix of expats, both from Europe and Asia. At least it was cheap, though it was nearly vomit inducing.
author: Celeste T.

description:
I tried out this place today after going to Yong Kee http://www.yelp.com/biz/yong-kee-san-francisco#hrid:UraXjy3x3fLakqfOCz3cYg for buns and, upon remembering that I was not impressed with their ha gow last time, decided to try this place for my dim sum needs.

Worst idea ever! They looked fine from the outside and their dumplings were huge, but it was some of the greasiest dim sum I've ever eaten. I got 3 pieces of shiu mai and 3 pieces of ha gow. The shiu mai was fine, but too greasy... all you could taste was oil and salt. The ha gow were chewy... not as in the shrimp was chewy but the wrappers were chewy. They were almost crunchy at the edges as if they'd been in the case for god knows how long. Of all the places on this street, why did I have to make such a bad decission?

The service was  inattentive and slow too, especially for a takeout place. All in all, this place would be 2 stars were it not for the price. It was $3.90 for 6 pieces of dim sum. Normally, I would not consider that a bad price if it had been GOOD dim sum, but I paid almost $4 for crap when I could have paid about $3 for "not great but certainly not crap" dim sum elsewhere.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Hole in the wall place.  Doesn't look all that clean.  Not a very good selection of dim sum.  To make matters worse, everything is served on a single thin paper plate.  So why four stars?

Because what they do have, it's tasty.  And cheap.  Hella cheap.

I ordered enough to eat there, and then added some stuff to go.  And the whole thing cost me $6.2.  What??  I've eaten here several times now and brought co-workers and friends too.  The red-bean filled mochi patties are especially yummy.  And the char-siu pastries are excellent too.

Best of all, it's a 10-minute walk from the office.  It's a good little cheap, hole in the wall place that warrants frequent visits.
author: Yuan W.

description:
Very mediocre. We stopped in for a quick bite today after brunch #1 at La Lola.  Got spinach dumplings, pork dumplings (1 beef for the no porker) and 1 stick rice in lotus leaf.  Meh pretty much sums it up.

We watched her stick the plate with all of our food into the microwave to reheat it.  The food stuck to the plate and was not so tasty due to the microwave torture.  We didn't like the sticky rice at all.

Only positive was that it was cheap and there was ample seating upstairs.
author: Aaron T.

description: This was probably the worst chinese restaurant I've ever been to. The food was perfectly equated with the service: HORRIBLE. The lady who served us our food was rude and unclear. Sadly, the food she served us didn't make up for her bad attitude. I hope anyone visiting the beautiful San Francisco will never find themselves eating in a place that represents chinese culture and food in the city as badly as this place does. There are millions of better places to go. Believe me.
author: Ethan P.

description: I was here really early in the morning my first full day in San Francisco because I was still on eastern time. We asked our hotel concierge if there were any dim sum places open yet, and this is where she directed us. Since they had literally just opened, the food was really fresh. I'm guessing that's not the case latter on in the day. We were starving, and ordered tons of food. The woman behind the counter threw everything on one plate then put it in the microwave for about a minute. Certainly not ideal, but the food was still pretty good...like I said though, we were their first customers, I'm not sure how well the food would hold up throughout the day. 2 bubble teas, plus a massive plate of random dim sum was about $15, so definitely a bargain.
author: Allyson P.

description: It's been a long time since I have been here.  Back then, it was not called "House of Dim Sum.  I presumed change of ownership.  Well, time have change and NOT FOR THE BEST.  It's quite expensive if you only bought a dozen pork buns, 3 egg custards and 3 small baked pork ( $18.00).  They probably charged me more thinking my wife and I were tourist.  Too bad.  Next time, we'll go somewhere else. However,  if you want to get ripped off, come to this place.
author: Richard M.

description:
I feel bad only giving two stars, cuz typically, I won't go out of my way to return to a two-star kinda place;  However, I can't justify that complete third star, BUT I can almost guarantee I'll be back here again because of its proximity to the Foot Reflexology Center, awesome prices and great memories made today.

Today's trip to House of Dim Sum was an unplanned afternoon outing with the sisters, immediately following our one hour foot reflexology appts.  down the street.  I know, I know... we really should've just been 'good' and had some tea to wash away all the toxins, but we were ALL famished!

Now, the chances of all three of us, together, in Chinatown, are rare, so how could I say no to any of my sister's requests!  My youngest sister is the type of person who feels lost outside of San Mateo - the city, not the county (yes, it's pretty bad), so we hit the streets fulfilling her tourist fantasies (Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Company, too?  OF COURSE!)

Our appetites ordered way too much food, so despite the $20 we spent, we calculated that we could've brought it down to approx. $14 (crazy overeating Americans).

Our choices today:
- Shrimp Dumpling, 2 orders, 4 for $2
- Chives & Shrimp Dumpling 4 for $2 (I will come back for this alone!)
- Baked BBQ Pork Bun 3 @ .80 (HUGE buns)
- Fresh Shrimp Rice Noodle, two orders @ $2
- Sesame Seed Ball 4 for $2
- Egg Custard Pie 3 @ .50
- Porridge 3 @ $1.50

We were all very happy with the dishes - but what's up with no little sauce dishes and the 1/2 ply paper plates???  I was super tempted to go down the street, buy some cheap melamine plate ware just so we could dip appropriately!  Well, obviously we got over it, and ate to our hearts' content with kikkoman puddles on our thin layers of paper.

Nothing really sticks out about this specific dim sum place, but the two ladies at the counter were really friendly and nice.  Also, I tend to be really sentimental about things, so hopefully I'll get my sisters out here again for another sister day in one of my favorite neighborhoods of the city.
author: Olma M.

description:
The place is dumpy, yes, even for Chinatown standard.  

Nothing is great, just ok at best.  We recently had their dried shrimp noodle roll and stir fried sticky rice.  Price is cheap like other places but the taste and quality are lacking.  Both lack ingredients.  The noodle roll was too sticky and the sticky rice was dry.

What can be worse?  They unknowingly (or knowingly) hired the loud pushy lady that once haunted patrons at Broadway Dim Sum.

With just ok food and a terrible sales, chances of us returning is likely zero.
author: Gloria H.

description: Some of my food was cold, and I feel like it wasn't as cheap as other places, but it was tasty, and the meat was of decent quality, which tends to be one of the most important factors for me.
author: Chris M.

description: Typical Chinatown Dim Sum shop. Not too fancy.....not really clean......simple dim sum items, fair prices.  If you want fancy, you have  to pay for it at Yang Sing. I will award three stars.
author: Steve D.

description:
I don't even want to give this place 1 star, but you're forced to select one. This place was horrible. I'm from Los Angeles & maybe it's just a geographical thing in terms how dim-sum is served,  but I was looking for a dim-sum joint that has people pushing carts & such. It seems like Chinatown San Francisco did not have them. Needless to say, after walking several blocks, we decided to give this place a try. BIG MISTAKE! You walk in, select the items you want behind the glass counter then they microwave them!! Just what I want, my shu-mai or so-called steamed dumplings nice & hard. Customer Service is definitely lacking which I feel is expected in most small shops, but there...THEY DIDN'T CARE ONE BIT. Just buy our stuff & get the heck out!! We don't care if you don't like it or not. Rude was surely an understatement. 

My final thoughts...If you're looking for a dim-sum joint with carts & such, you won't find it here. It's more of a take-out type place. The food was horrible. Customer Service will be seriously lacking unless you speak the language. Don't get me wrong, it's not that you have to be Chinese to be treated great, but niceness, politeness a.k.a "customer service" to people who are buying your food should be high on any restaurants list of getting return customers. Good luck if you try this place.
author: Robert C.

description:
Mind you I'd give this place five stars if they didn't serve tea in styrofoam cups, which despite being majorly sacreligous in and of itself, is well made up for with the sumptuous food and mind-boggling prices!

Two or three aunties (I like to refer to kind, older Chinese ladies as "aunties") will greet you warmly in this semi-cafeteria style hole-in-the-wall eatery. Order as much as you like because it won't go much over five or six dollars before the aunties fill up your plate before your eyes.

Order to go or for dine in, it's all the same to them. If you're on the go it's great for a snack out the door as well (though not recommended if you're taking the Stockton 30).

Great tasting and wallet friendly, House of Dim Sum will always have a special place in my heart.
author: Stuart Y.

description: Amazing quality dim sum and incredible price. Chinese locals eat there for a reason. Staff was very friendly and helpful. Poor decoration and furniture and dirty restrooms but you should go there if you are looking for authentic dim sum.
author: Catalina U.

description: Service is okay and the place is clean but the dim sum was not anything special. The best part was that you can sit down and eat, a rare plus in a neighborhood of to-go joints. Pork bun was good but I wouldn't go back again just for that.
author: M K.

description: Found this little gem while strolling through china town with a friend. We had hit up numerous spots thinking that we had plenty of options to eat some dimsum. What we failed to noticed was that all the restaurants closed at 2. Luckily we found House of dim sum and were able to get our fixing. They have really good prices and quick service. A for sure hole in the wall.
author: Valerie G.

description: Food looked great, until it got put in the microwave. The place is dirty and the food tasted horrible. After a few bites, it went right in the trash. Luckily I ordered a pepsi with my meal so I could wash my mouth out. Pure crap. Avoid at all costs.
author: John P.

description:
You won't find anything too fancy at this little hole in the wall, just the basic shrimp/pork/chive dumplings, chow fun, and congee (Chinese rice porridge), but it all hits the spot.  The ladies behind the counter are friendly and the food is wonderfully cheap!  (As in "I got 9 shrimp dumplings, a large Chinese porridge, a huge Chinese doughnut to dip into the porridge, a couple of pieces of rolled shrimp chow fun and a Diet Coke for $9 and some change" cheap.  Yeah, I'm hella hungry, so what?).

If the tables in the front of the store are occupied, you can go upstairs.  The best part about this place is it's location: in the heart of Chinatown, and delightful to walk to from the Financial District...
author: Karen F.

description:
If I was ever to leave a 1 star review, now's the time.  This place was awful.  I was in Chinatown for a couple hours, finished running some errands with a friend, went back to where I parked my car on Jackson St, right in front of this rat hole.  Unfortunately the dim sum joint I've been to before across the street looked closed, so we gave this place a try.
I wasn't expecting friendly service, us being in Chinatown, so this horrible rating is strictly based on the food.
We ordered the standards, some shrimp dumplings, shuimai, veggie dumplings, and turnip cake.  I couldn't believe my eyes when I saw the lady nuke our order in the microwave.  Never in my life have I seen a restaurant reheat dim sum in a microwave.  The taste was blah, and I would've just walked out a little disappointed. What brings the rating down from 2 stars to 1 is the horrible aftertaste, and an upset stomach.
How is this place still open?  Oh yeah, the passerby who didn't know any better.
author: Don S.

description:
Disappointing.  However, what can one expect when dumplings, shumai, and rice cake are attempted to be warmed in a microwave.  To start, we were looking for dim sum in Chinatown.  Checking our yelp apps on our phones, we stopped by several that had long lineups (4-stars).  We ended up going across the street to House of Dim Sum because, hey, with a name like that, you shouldn't be disappointed.  Looks okay, as one would expect in the area.  70s like building, that hasn't been updated in awhile.  Oh well, the lady helping us seems cheery, let's take a chance (come to think of it, she's most likely cheery because there are customers).  We order a few dumplings, shumai, and a rice cake.  Next thing you know, it's on a plate and being thrown into a microwave.  We all kind of stop, and don't know what to make of it.  Oh well, we are starving and have made the long trek up and down the hill.  Let's order a few more things.  Alright, those aren't in the microwave.  We get our food, sit down, and we each eat a shrimp dumpling, which is bleh.  Then on to the shumai.  Ummmm, seriously?  The three of us are fighting gag reflexes.  We had a few plates with different dumplings on it...what a waste.  All lukewarm at best.  One minute in the microwave did nothing.  The food must have been room temperature or colder.  We ask for a to-go box and the ladies look at us funny.  I wanted to tell them that the food was horrible, but I knew it would fall on deaf ears.  I had seen the two cooks come out to hand over the cooked food to the ladies, and they looked uninspired and all around gloomy.  Definitely a reflection of their food.  We left and wanted to give the food to a homeless person, but we felt that they wouldn't even eat it.  They probably know where to find the good food!  We were fighting gag reflexes for half an hour...

To sum: horrible.  They must have just discovered the microwave...at an antique store.  Besides, any time you need a microwave, you are cooking too much food ahead of time.  You shouldn't even be serving food.  Their steamer did not keep anything warm.  Chinese food needs a make over here in the US.  I am embarassed for these Chinese restaurants.  I'm more sad that people have to grow up thinking this food is really what it is supposed to be like.

About me: I am spoiled by being within driving distance to Vancouver, BC.  Anywhere you go: you order, they make, they serve.  FRESH. No carts, no microwaves.
author: Dereck G.

description:
I boycotted this place for 2 reasons. 1) they got mad at me for giving them 20 pennies.... hey, its still money and 2) they spilled my jook and then tried to put it back into the container.... ugh....

other than that, food is ok. oh yes, one day a pigeon flew in there and sat on top of some of the items in the windows. I think it was the fried doughnuts for the jook. The lady just grabbed it by the wings and threw it out the window. She didn't wash her hands or dumped out the item in the window that the pigeon sat on. ugh
author: Jay S.

description: A different sort of dim sum place. Fresh, tasty dim sum, super-low prices and bustling counter service give this ghetto place a unique energetic vibe (at least at mealtimes). No plates here; it's only plastic bags and trays. Sit down space is limited and unattractive but the place is well-located as a  provisioning center for a picturesque Telegraph Hill picnic.
author: Sempro S.

description: I came here looking for this other dim sum restaurant, but this place didn't disappoint.  The lady working there was definitely not in a great mood, but what else is new, right?  I'm half Chinese, I know what it's all about.  Anyway, we tried the charsiew bao and the shrimp dumplings, and both were delicious.  I'll be coming back the next time I'm in the area.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I always come to this place several times for breakfast when I am in San Fran.  It is a "hole in the wall" place, no frills (to say the least.) 

You don't see anyone but Asians here for the most part (which I find to be a good indication of authentic food.)  Plastic trays and paper plates, and go upstairs to stay out of the wind from the open front door.

The dim sum is very good and the prices are amazing.  For TWO people, a variety of sim sum (with hot tea) runs about $7.00.  Be sure to get the sticky rice steamed in lotus leaf and the har gow (shrimp dumplings.)
author: Bill M.

description:
how does this place get such shitty reviews? 

i love the girl behind the counter .she always remembers my "usual" and reminds me that it's been a long time since i've seen her (even if it has only been 2 days). 

i crave your won ton soup every fortnight. forget the colonel! i'm all about the dim sum.
author: Meryl Q.

description: BEWARE! The clerk that accepts money and prepares food uses the same gloves giving you coin change! I was disgusted. My noodle roll was cold and she did not offered to heat it up for me. Worst of all she did not give me any eye contact or said "thank you". Will definitely not be back. I threw my noodle roll away.
author: Jimmy C.

description: Got the Char Shu Bao after running the Chinatown 10K this morning.  It was raining and my car was parked right in front of the store, so I wandered in.  Ate the Char Shu Bao today for a mid-afternoon snack.  Impressive!  I'd rank it almost as good as the Char Shu Bao at Ruby King in Oakland or Good Luck Dim Sum on Clement, and those are my two favorite.
author: David L.

description: Well I was here just this past Saturday.  I was in the mood for some dim sum.  I bought a large order of jook (porridge), lor mai guen (sticky rice wrapped in bread), ja leurng (chinese fried donut wrapped in white noodle), siu lung bow (steamed pork dumplings), and gow choy gau (chive filled dumplings).  I must say the jook was really good.  It was better then any dim sum places I've been to.  The siu lung bow was okay, as well as the gow choy gau.  The ja leurng isn't all that bad.  This is one the only places that I know of (that is dim sum shops) that have ja leurng.  With regards to decor, it's not the most cleanliness of places, but it's not the dirtiest either.  I must admit the best tasting item was the jook.  I do intend to return to this place.
author: Philip L.

description: This place is awful. Oh man, I wanted to try something different than my usual run to Good Mong Kok and boy, what a mistake. I ordered a few shrimp dumplings, chive dumplings, and another item that looks like rice noodle with beef or pork inside. First of all, I was charged $7!!! That is outlandish for a hole-in-the-wall place in Chinatown. The food was awful, even if it costs $1. Really oily and they microwave the food before they serve it to you. This made the dumpling skin really chewy and hard. The lady taking order is nice and understands English but that can't make up for the bad food. You'll be better off going to one of the other excellent dim sum places in Chinatown.
author: Khoi N.

description:
I have to strongly disagree with my fellow yelpers. Many do not understand that chinese fast food places are different from burger king and mac donalds. They steam the buns and dim sum in large quantities in the kitchen. Afterwards they place them in a steamer that is under the counter. Therefore, the dim sum is always warm and fresh. They give you an option of microwaving your food if you prefer it to be warmer or not. Either way, the dim sum is still delicious.

Also, many do not realize that the prices here are nearly half the price that you normally purchase dim sum for. One order of dim sum is only $1.50. There's not too many places where you could get it at this price. So all you tourists and inexperienced people out there, don't criticize this place if you do not truly have the real experience of chinese dining.
author: Kelvin C.

description:
I work in SOMA, my friend, the conch, works in the financial district and I desperately needed to buy a kite.

Found the one I wanted at a kite shop in Chinatown.  Perfect, I told the conch I would swing by her way and we could go on a little Chinatown adventure. Kites, those cool red and gold shoes, most likely made by children in sweatshops, dim sum and tourists.

I ended up being dragged to Macy's to buy women's underthings.  I still think she should have purchased the pink ones.   And maybe there wasn't actual dragging.

The kite shop had just what I was looking for and more.  Chinatown Kite Shop.

Then we decided to check Yelp to find a decent Dim Sum place.  As we were both on our phones, we did a quick lookup and saw several places on Jackson had 4 stars, so headed that direction.

House of Dim Sum had 4 stars and the food in the window looked decent.  Of course, now that I'm back in my office, House of Dim Sum now has 3 stars.  Perhaps someone had the same afternoon the conch and I did.

We stopped in, ordered a few dumplings, rice noodles, steamed and pastry items.  We both went for the dumplings first.  Not bad, probably the only thing I would order here again if I had to go back.  The wrapping was a bit too thick, but that seemed to be a general theme of the dim sum here.  The shrimp and chive dumpling had a piece of shrimp...as in a portion of a whole shrimp.  The conch thought it was the spinach dumpling I had ordered, until I directed her to what on the plate was the actual spinach dumpling.

Same problem with the rice noodles.  The noodle was too thick, a little gummy, and contained one shrimp, although, I think this was one whole shrimp.  And none of that cool sauce I like to get at a sit down place.   Although this has seating, it is definitely not a sit down place.

The steamed pork buns held a decently flavored filling, but it was like sifting through a mouthful of cotton balls to find it.

If I were VERY, VERY hungover, it might be just the kind of carb laden meal I was looking for.

After the pork buns, well, I can't really tell you what came next.  Neither of us remember ordering this large steamed item; but there it was, on our plastic tray, looking strikingly like a mini Frisbee disk.  Hmmm, the conch tried it first,  and told me not to bother.  But bother, I did.  And was rewarded for my efforts.  She had only discovered the hard boiled egg hidden inside, but I was the lucky one to happen upon the piece of congealed sausage tucked inbetween said egg and a chicken like substance.  The wind blew through the open door at this point blowing my napkins over the top of our flying discus, and we both agreed we were happy we didn't know what it was, as we would not order the mystery item again.

And then we moved on to the pastry.  The dough was flaky, but a bit undercooked.  The flavors reminded us of that good dim sum you can get.  If only these pastries weren't cold, had even a touch of heat to push it over the edge from doughy to flaky perfection.  If only.  It was like eating a cold Pop-Tart.  And I'll admit, those are edible, but toasted...wow, you just can't recover from a memory like that.  So close on this one, House of Dim Sum, so close.  But this isn't horseshoes, or grenades.

Or maybe it is.  Because the first thing the conch and I noticed as we left the restaurant was a leaden tightness in our stomaches.  Much as I would expect to feel upon swallowing a horseshoe, or being kicked with one.

I was torn between one and two stars on this one.  I'll give this place 2, as the food wasn't greasy, the dumplings were edible and hey, I had a lot of fun and left with the promise of going out w/ the conch again to find another, better dim sum place.
author: g m.

description: 'Dim Sum's were great... The presentation was not (which I don't really mind).
author: The M.

description: While we were on a Princess coastal cruise back to L.A. one of our stop was San Francisco. my quest was to find really good dim sum. both husband and I walked all over Chinatown and came across this place and decided to buy a couple of Sui Mei and Ha gow, it was so delicious. I wanted more but I was a little full from having breakfast on the cruise ship. we decided to walk around more and check out the shops and later came back to this place and got 2 baked bao to take along with us back to the ship. they were so huge and delicious. we were so surprised this place only charged $1.00 each for these delicious baked bao. if you're ever in San Francisco chinatown, stop by this place buy these inexpensive delightful buns.
author: Chris M.

description:
If you love dirty floors, walls and counters along with some spoiled pork?   this is the place to be...  

My wife and I read some of the reviews here and thought, hey it cant be that bad.  When I got there, I chose to ignore the old and stale looking noodles and just asked for 2 of each of the dim sum.  When I paid for the food, she took the food out of the MICROWAVE!  Some of the noodles fell out of the plate and she scooped them back on to my plate.  NICE!  After one bite of the pork dim sum, I started gagging and almost threw up!  It smelled like the pork has been sitting in a storage room underground for weeks!  DO NOT GO HERE.  I cant stand people who do not realize that they are serving garbage!
author: Amir I.

description: Mmm, dim sum, my tasty foray into Chinese brunch cuisine continues with my third restaurant visited... I liked this place because you save soooo much money when you don't sit down and have the ladies push their carts around, bringing the dim sum to you.  Sure, that's a nice experience, but this trip's goal was to score cheap dim sum in an aunthentic 'hole in the wall' type place, as the previous reviewer says... however, I didn't mind House of Dim Sum's atmosphere at all... we just pointed out what we wanted downstairs to the nice ladies behind the counter, carried it all upstairs on our trays, and chowed down, all for only about $7 a person, including a couple of drinks and leftovers at the end to take home.  Sure the place was rustic, but that's all part of the experience of stuffing your face with Sunday morning dim sum in Chinatown.  It all tasted good to me, so I'd say go for it.
author: Canadian A.

description: Mediocre dim sum.  Cheap though.  Sticky rice was awesome.
author: Matt N.

description: The only decent dim sum in SF, but I got sick the last time I went there.  It's good, but ask them to nuke the food longer than they usually do.
author: Christopher L.

description: What a hole in the wall :)  I found it while stomping around Chinatown as a tourist.  Saw a group of people hanging around outside this place eating.  I looked in the window and the pork buns looked yummy so I went in.  Ordered a plateful of this and that and sat upstairs to eat.  Was very good, I'm glad i went in.  This will become a treasured "I found this place all by myself" story.  Can't rate it higher than 3 stars, tho, was really a complete dive (But pretty clean(!) just completely undecorated) and the counter lady seemed more interested in putting things on my plate than letting me decide - but a good place with solid food worth visiting.
author: Eric B.

description: Don't go here! We just ordered a bunch of dishes and the food was so inedible that we threw half of it away.  They microwave your food, you are served on paper plates.  Total waste of money.
author: sam h.

description:
probably THEE best $1 cha siu bao i've tried in SF... 

note that i am NOT chinese, so don't be talking crap because i'm korean...but then again iono what's GOOD GOOD cha siu bao, so any input is greatly appreciated!

haven't tried their dimsum and even though i'm not chinese, i DO know my food, since i'm exposing myself to eat different types of food on a daily basis .. check out my daily yelp reviews -- something new ... haha... 

what's the perfect foodie to get when you're in a rush to avoid SF traffic (does SF even HAVE traffic?) or eat something that is quite worthwhile rather than munching on those damn pretzels/peanuts on the plane? 

what's even better is, i betcha that youd be scrambling for every penny possible in your car (no need for me to fill up my meters since i got my meter card!) and be lucky enough to score a $1 cha siu bao. give it a shot, you won't be disappointed!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Tried it on a whim after a bit of wandering around. Obviously we didn't come for the service or the decor, but if you don't have those you could at least have tasty food. Decent selection but flavor-wise this was bad-to-mediocre at best. Certainly could have been worse, but didn't have too much to recommend itself either.
author: Jessica B.

description: Walked up here from the TransAmerica building after knocking the lunch idea around for a bit. After wandering up the hill I was excited to see shrimp dumplings, lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice with chicken, turnip cake, and pork dumplings. Upon getting back to the office I hungrily devoured the shrimp dumplings, which were only ok. It might have been that I was hungry, but they seemed pretty tasty. Moving on the turnip cake. It was a cold gelatinous square. Aside from being the wrong temperature it had too much pepper and not enough chopped up bits of goodness. If you are a turnip cake eater - you know what I mean. The potstickers were greasy and the wrapper was too thick. Ugh. Disappointing.  Finally I get around to the wrapped chicken, which was ok - decent, but doesn't merit a return trip. All in all I spent $5.50, but I don't feel like I got a deal. I'm full but far from satisfied. I would have much rather paid more and had something tastier and worth the caloric intake.
author: Stacy T.
